alt_names: Atka Island|Atka Post|Adak Island|Adak Post|Adak Naval Station|Amchitka Island|Amchitka Post|Kiska Island|Kiska Post|Shemya Island|Shemya Post|Shemya Air Force Base|Eareckson Air Force Station|Agattu Island|Attu Island|Camp Earle|Attu Post
description_raw: Aleutian Islands WWII History Atka Island : The U.S. Army established Atka Post in 1942. Adak Island : An Army airfield ( Adak Post ) and Navy base ( Adak Naval Station ) protected by two 6-inch naval guns. Several 155mm guns on Panama mounts were located at Zeto Point (mounts still intact). An AMTB battery was located at Kruluk Bay. Sixty AA guns were emplaced around the island. Restricted public access. Amchitka Island : The U.S. Army established Amchitka Post in 1943. The Army airfield was protected by eight 155mm guns on Panama mounts located at Constantine Harbor (mounts still intact). Several machine-gun pillboxes still remain along the airfield. Restricted public access. Kiska Island : Captured and fortified by Japan 1942 - 1943. Japanese guns still remaining on the island (at North Head) include one 4.7-inch quick-firing M1905 British gun, one 6-inch M1900 British gun, four 150mm naval guns, one 140mm coast defense gun, four 120mm dual-purpose guns, and several 3-inch M1900 British guns. One 6-inch M1894 British gun is still located on Little Kiska Island. The Japanese evacuated after losing Attu Island. The U.S. Army then established Kiska Post in 1943. (Special thanks to Dirk Spennemann, Colt Denfeld, and Glen Williford of the Coast Defense Study Group for providing Japanese gun data and current status) Shemya Island : The U.S. Army established Shemya Post in 1943, including an airstrip. An AMTB battery still remains in situ, and possibly one or two other batteries were located here. Shemya Air Force Base was renamed Eareckson Air Force Station in 1993. Still active as a subpost of Elmendorf Air Force Base. Restricted public access. Agattu Island : Captured by Japan and briefly held in 1942. Not fortified by the U.S. Army. Attu Island : Captured and fortified by Japan 1942 - 1943. One 75mm AA Japanese gun still remains. Recaptured by the U.S. Army in 1943 who then established Camp Earle (aka Attu Post ). Several 155mm guns on Panama mounts were located at Chichagof Point. Also emplaced were 21 AA guns. Restricted public access. Attu Battlefield and Army-Navy Airfields info by NPS. (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)

description_raw: A U.S. Army Air Corps field with two 5000-foot runways, later extended to 6000 and 7500 feet. Beginning in May 1942 the base was primarily used by the Royal Canadian Air Force for bombers (115 Squadron) and fighters (118 Squadron) used in the front-line defense of Prince Rupert , BC. There was at least one Canadian Heavy AA gun battery, located at the southern end of the runway. A Canadian Infantry camp was located at Moss Point. All Canadian troops here were under Canadian command, until withdrawn in November 1943. A U.S. Navy seaplane base and fuel depot was located at Crab Point in Tamgas Harbor. American coastal defenses included a four-gun 155mm gun battery on Panama mounts located on Davison Point (mounts still remain), and two 6-inch naval guns located at Smuggler Cove (gone). Fire-control towers were located at Yellow Hill, Mid Point, Davison Point, Warburton Island, Hotspur Island, and Callaghan Island. Searchlight towers were located at Mid Point, Warburton Island, Hotspur Island, and Callaghan Island. (see also Prince Rupert Harbour Defences , British Columbia)

description_raw: Established to protect the railroad that was under construction at the time. Located one mile north of town. Fort Richardson / Elmendorf Field was established nearby in 1940. The main cantonment of Fort Richardson moved in 1950 to its present site, and the original post became Elmendorf Air Force Base . This is the headquarters post for U.S. Army Alaska and the Alaska National Guard.

description_raw: A U.S. Army Engineer and Quartermaster post. Three barge docks, sheds, oil docks, cold storage buildings, warehouses, tank farm, marine repair facility, water reservoir, and barracks for up to 4000 troops were constructed. The post was not completed until after the Japanese evacuated the Aleutians, and was therefore abandoned without any use. There were no known defenses. The base was dismantled by imported German POWs from Colorado from June 1945 to November 1945. The remaining buildings were sold off in January 1946.

The community, also known today as Nanwalek , was the oldest Russian settlement on the Alaska mainland.

description_raw: An American post with a one-square mile reservation. Also spelled Kenai . A replica blockhouse was built in 1967 close to the original site. First located here was the Russian Fort St. Nicholas (1791 - 1797 ?), built by the Lebedef - Lastochkin Company. Alternate names for the Russian fort are Nikolaevsk Redoubt, Fort Nikolaya, Kenai Redoubt, Paul's Fort, Fort St. Paul , and Pavlovskaya Redoubt . It was attacked by Dena'ina Indians in 1797.

description_raw: An American post. Also spelled Kadiak , the popular spelling until 1901. Located nearby was the Russian stockaded blockhouse Fort Pavlosk (1792 - 1868), the first headquarters for the Russian fur trade until 1808. An extant Russian-built warehouse, located at 101 East Marine Way, and known today as the Erskine House , was originally built in 1808 by the Russian-American Company. It was later used in 1868 by the American Alaska Commercial Company. It was sold in 1911 as a private residence.In 1967 it became the Baranov Museum (admission fee), operated by the Kodiak Historical Society. It is the oldest Russian-built wooden building still extant in Alaska, and one of only four original Russian structures still extant in the United States. The first white (Russian) settlement was actually located nearby at Three Saints Bay ( Old Harbor ) in 1784.

description_raw: An Army airfield and Navy section base. A two-gun 6-inch naval gun battery was located at Grant Point. One remaining gun is on display near the town dump. (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)

description_raw: A Russian trading post located at the mouth of the Kasilof River, built by the Lebedef - Lastochkin Company. The Russian-American Company took over in 1799. It was burned down sometime before the Americans took possession of Alaska in 1867. Also called Kasilof River Post and Fort Kussilof . In 1817 it was known as Fort Georgiyevsk , probably rebuilt at that time with a defensive earthwork.
entry_raw: Fort St. George (1786 - unknown), Kasilof - A Russian trading post located at the mouth of the Kasilof River, built by the Lebedef - Lastochkin Company. The Russian-American Company took over in 1799. It was burned down sometime before the Americans took possession of Alaska in 1867. Also called Kasilof River Post and Fort Kussilof . In 1817 it was known as Fort Georgiyevsk , probably rebuilt at that time with a defensive earthwork.

description_raw: A Hudson's Bay Co. post at Point Highfield, about four miles up from the mouth of the Stikine River. Also (or later) called Fort Highfield , and was erroneously called Fort Durham (2) in some British reports. Originally this was the Russian Redoubt St. Dionysius (1834 - 1840), a log-stockaded blockhouse which was built to keep the Hudson's Bay Company out of the area. It was handed over to the British in 1840 on a ten-year lease. Fort Stikine was transferred to the Hudson's Bay Company from the Russian American Fur Company on a ten-year lease in 1839. James Douglas received possession of Stikine, located near the mouth of the Stikine River, in June 1840. In April 1842, surgeon and clerk in charge of Stikine, John McLoughlin Jr. was murdered at the post by HBC servant Urbain Heroux. Stikine was closed in 1849 and trade in the region was carried on by HBC coasting vessels based at Fort Victoria (BC).
entry_raw: Fort Stikine (1840 - 1849), near Wrangell - A Hudson's Bay Co. post at Point Highfield, about four miles up from the mouth of the Stikine River. Also (or later) called Fort Highfield , and was erroneously called Fort Durham (2) in some British reports. Originally this was the Russian Redoubt St. Dionysius (1834 - 1840), a log-stockaded blockhouse which was built to keep the Hudson's Bay Company out of the area. It was handed over to the British in 1840 on a ten-year lease. Fort Stikine was transferred to the Hudson's Bay Company from the Russian American Fur Company on a ten-year lease in 1839. James Douglas received possession of Stikine, located near the mouth of the Stikine River, in June 1840. In April 1842, surgeon and clerk in charge of Stikine, John McLoughlin Jr. was murdered at the post by HBC servant Urbain Heroux. Stikine was closed in 1849 and trade in the region was carried on by HBC coasting vessels based at Fort Victoria (BC).

description_raw: A Hudson's Bay Co. 150-foot square stockaded trading post, with two octagonal blockhouses at the corners, officially called Fort Durham (1) . Located at the extreme northeast corner of Taku Harbor, on the eastern side of the outlet for Taku Lake. Abandoned for Fort Victoria, BC, due to poor economic conditions. NOTE: Stockade Point, at the southern entrance to Taku Harbor, was named by the Americans in 1869 on the wrong assumption that Fort Taku was once there. (thanks to Wallace Olson, of Heritage Research, for providing info)

description_raw: An American military fort built here one month before Fort Wrangel.
entry_raw: Fort Tongass (1868 - 1870), Tongass Island - An American military fort built here one month before Fort Wrangel.

description_raw: An American military fort. The original Russian spelling was later changed to Wrangell . The British Hudson's Bay Co. Wrangell Post (1898 - 1901) was also here. Wrangell post was established in 1898 on Wrangell Island, Alaska as a means of securing business for the HBC's steamers. The HBC had previously established a presence on Wrangell Island in 1866, but by the following year operations were ceased. In 1899 Wrangell was closed and a local merchant acted as the HBC's agent in the region until circa 1901.
entry_raw: Fort Wrangel (1868 - 1870, 1874 - 1877, 1898 - 1900), Wrangell, Wrangell Island - An American military fort. The original Russian spelling was later changed to Wrangell . The British Hudson's Bay Co. Wrangell Post (1898 - 1901) was also here. Wrangell post was established in 1898 on Wrangell Island, Alaska as a means of securing business for the HBC's steamers. The HBC had previously established a presence on Wrangell Island in 1866, but by the following year operations were ceased. In 1899 Wrangell was closed and a local merchant acted as the HBC's agent in the region until circa 1901.

description_raw: Originally a Hudson's Bay Co. post, composed of three log buildings within a 100-foot square stockade, and a blockhouse in each corner. The Russians allowed (or did not fully realize) the presence of the British in this area, but the Americans came in 1869 and ordered them out. The HBC had already rebuilt the fort one mile away in 1864 due to erosion problems. The U.S. Army reoccupied the site in 1897 to help local miners. Fort Yukon was established on the Yukon River, near its junction with the Porcupine (Rat) River in present-day Alaska in 1847. In the 1850's Fort Yukon was maintained as the basis for HBC operations west of the Mackenzie Mountains. Fort Yukon was rebuilt in 1864. In 1867 Alaska was purchased by the United States of America; subsequently, Fort Yukon was moved 70 miles higher up the Yukon River out of American territory. The HBC built a post at this location and renamed it Rampart House.
entry_raw: Fort Yukon (1847 - 1869, 1897 - 1898), Fort Yukon - Originally a Hudson's Bay Co. post, composed of three log buildings within a 100-foot square stockade, and a blockhouse in each corner. The Russians allowed (or did not fully realize) the presence of the British in this area, but the Americans came in 1869 and ordered them out. The HBC had already rebuilt the fort one mile away in 1864 due to erosion problems. The U.S. Army reoccupied the site in 1897 to help local miners. Fort Yukon was established on the Yukon River, near its junction with the Porcupine (Rat) River in present-day Alaska in 1847. In the 1850's Fort Yukon was maintained as the basis for HBC operations west of the Mackenzie Mountains. Fort Yukon was rebuilt in 1864. In 1867 Alaska was purchased by the United States of America; subsequently, Fort Yukon was moved 70 miles higher up the Yukon River out of American territory. The HBC built a post at this location and renamed it Rampart House.

description_raw: A two-gun 6-inch naval gun battery was located one mile west of town near the end of Marks Army Airfield (present-day Nome Airport). The guns still exist, but the emplacement was damaged by the effects of nearby gold dredging operations. (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)
entry_raw: Nome Post (1941 - 1946), Nome - A two-gun 6-inch naval gun battery was located one mile west of town near the end of Marks Army Airfield (present-day Nome Airport). The guns still exist, but the emplacement was damaged by the effects of nearby gold dredging operations. (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)

description_raw: A WWII Army post and airfield ( Reeve Field ) protecting the Alaska Highway.
entry_raw: Northway Post (1942 - 1945), Northway Junction - A WWII Army post and airfield ( Reeve Field ) protecting the Alaska Highway.

description_raw: An American trading post built by the Pioneer Company about 12 miles below the confluence of the Yukon and Tanana Rivers (on Station Island ?) It was the first American post on the Yukon River. The post was bought by the Parrott and Company around 1870. Possibly the same as Fort Adams above.
entry_raw: Nukluroyit Station (1868 - unknown), near Tanana - An American trading post built by the Pioneer Company about 12 miles below the confluence of the Yukon and Tanana Rivers (on Station Island ?) It was the first American post on the Yukon River. The post was bought by the Parrott and Company around 1870. Possibly the same as Fort Adams above.

description_raw: A Russian blockhouse that was attacked and burned by Stikine Indians. Located about 16 miles south of Sitka at the outlet to Deep Lake.
entry_raw: Ozerskoye Redoubt (unknown - 1852), Baranof Island - A Russian blockhouse that was attacked and burned by Stikine Indians. Located about 16 miles south of Sitka at the outlet to Deep Lake.

description_raw: A two-gun 6-inch naval gun battery still remains at the old Navy base runway. The HECP bunker still exists. (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)
entry_raw: Popof Island Post (1942 - 1946), Sand Point, Popof Island - A two-gun 6-inch naval gun battery still remains at the old Navy base runway. The HECP bunker still exists. (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)

description_raw: A U.S. Army Corps of Engineers storehouse complex at Eagle Point. Four stone buildings were built to store supplies for the expedition to explore Portland Inlet and the surrounding area. At least two storehouses (#3 and #4) still exist. One was later used as a jail. These are the oldest masonry buildings in Alaska. Settlers and miners came to Hyder and Stewart , BC in 1898. Hyder was originally named Portland City .
entry_raw: Portland Inlet Depot (1896), Hyder - A U.S. Army Corps of Engineers storehouse complex at Eagle Point. Four stone buildings were built to store supplies for the expedition to explore Portland Inlet and the surrounding area. At least two storehouses (#3 and #4) still exist. One was later used as a jail. These are the oldest masonry buildings in Alaska. Settlers and miners came to Hyder and Stewart , BC in 1898. Hyder was originally named Portland City .

description_raw: A Hudson's Bay Co. post built on the Porcupine River to replace Fort Yukon. After a new boundary survey in 1890, the post had to be moved again. (see YUKON page) . Rampart House was established in the winter of 1869-1870 at the foot of the Upper Ramparts on the Porcupine River. Rampart House was built in response to the recognition that Fort Yukon was now located in American territory (Alaska was sold to the United States of America by Russia in 1867). In 1871 it was discovered that Rampart House was still located in American territory and it was abandoned. The HBC employees from Rampart House were sent to La Pierre's House (Yukon). In the fall of 1873, a small outstation was re-established as Rampart House to service the Draan'jik Gwich'in (Black River Indians). During the 1887-1888 season, it was again discovered that Rampart House was located within American territory, and in response the HBC burned the post buildings and erected new buildings twelve miles further up the Porcupine River. In 1889 a United States Coast and Geodetic Survey found that Rampart House was still 20 miles within American territory, and in 1890 the HBC again moved the post further up river. The last Rampart House, in Yukon Territory, was closed in 1893.

(see YUKON page) . Rampart House was established in the winter of 1869-1870 at the foot of the Upper Ramparts on the Porcupine River. Rampart House was built in response to the recognition that Fort Yukon was now located in American territory (Alaska was sold to the United States of America by Russia in 1867). In 1871 it was discovered that Rampart House was still located in American territory and it was abandoned. The HBC employees from Rampart House were sent to La Pierre's House (Yukon). In the fall of 1873, a small outstation was re-established as Rampart House to service the Draan'jik Gwich'in (Black River Indians). During the 1887-1888 season, it was again discovered that Rampart House was located within American territory, and in response the HBC burned the post buildings and erected new buildings twelve miles further up the Porcupine River. In 1889 a United States Coast and Geodetic Survey found that Rampart House was still 20 miles within American territory, and in 1890 the HBC again moved the post further up river. The last Rampart House, in Yukon Territory, was closed in 1893.

description_raw: An Army post on a remote island in the Bering Sea. The island was again in use by the military in WWII, with a military airfield. Also called St. Paul Post .
entry_raw: St. Paul Island Post (1869 - 1870, 1942 - 1945), St. Paul Island - An Army post on a remote island in the Bering Sea. The island was again in use by the military in WWII, with a military airfield. Also called St. Paul Post .

description_raw: A WWII Army post and airfield located across the Tanana River from town, protecting the Alaska Highway. Camp Tanacross (1961 - 1962) was a joint military winter training site for American and Canadian forces.
entry_raw: Tanacross Post (1942 - 1945), Tanacross - A WWII Army post and airfield located across the Tanana River from town, protecting the Alaska Highway. Camp Tanacross (1961 - 1962) was a joint military winter training site for American and Canadian forces.

description_raw: A WWII Army post. An AMTB battery may have been located here. The U.S. Army's Military Supply Terminal (1940 - 1960) was also established here. A few derelict buildings still remain alongside the dock area.
entry_raw: Whittier Post (1942 - 1945), Whittier - A WWII Army post. An AMTB battery may have been located here. The U.S. Army's Military Supply Terminal (1940 - 1960) was also established here. A few derelict buildings still remain alongside the dock area.

description_raw: A Russian (Sheilikof Company) fortified trade post where the Czar ordered the settlement of convicts.
entry_raw: Yakutat Bay Fort (1796 - unknown), Yakutat - A Russian (Sheilikof Company) fortified trade post where the Czar ordered the settlement of convicts.

description_raw: A two-gun 6-inch naval gun battery (partially destroyed) protected the military airfield here. A four-gun 155mm battery on Panama mounts was located at Point Carrow (mounts still remain). (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)
entry_raw: Yakutat Post (1940 - 1946), Yakutat - A two-gun 6-inch naval gun battery (partially destroyed) protected the military airfield here. A four-gun 155mm battery on Panama mounts was located at Point Carrow (mounts still remain). (info courtesy of Colt Denfeld of the Coast Defense Study Group)

description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort located five miles south of Coffeeville , on the west side of the Tombigbee River about one mile up Santa Bogue Creek, along the present-day Washington and Choctaw County boundary. It was soon abandoned.
entry_raw: (Wyche ?) Cato's Fort (1813), near Silver Cross - A settlers' stockaded fort located five miles south of Coffeeville , on the west side of the Tombigbee River about one mile up Santa Bogue Creek, along the present-day Washington and Choctaw County boundary. It was soon abandoned.

description_raw: An unnamed (?) log blockhouse built by General Jackson's troops at the confluence of the East and West Choctowatchee Rivers. A ferry was later established here. Marker on US 231 west of town erected in 1979.
entry_raw: 1814 Blockhouse (1814), near Midland City - An unnamed (?) log blockhouse built by General Jackson's troops at the confluence of the East and West Choctowatchee Rivers. A ferry was later established here. Marker on US 231 west of town erected in 1979.

description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort with two or three blockhouses, garrisoned by 13 men, later abandoned for Fort Republic at St. Stephens . The Choctaw reservation of Turkey Town was about three miles north on the Tombigbee River.
entry_raw: Abner Turner's Fort (1813), West Bend - A settlers' stockaded fort with two or three blockhouses, garrisoned by 13 men, later abandoned for Fort Republic at St. Stephens . The Choctaw reservation of Turkey Town was about three miles north on the Tombigbee River.

description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort located on the Wolf Trail leading from Burnt Corn to Pensacola , Florida. Later converted to a barn.
entry_raw: Alexander Autrey's Fort (1816), Conecuh County - A settlers' stockaded fort located on the Wolf Trail leading from Burnt Corn to Pensacola , Florida. Later converted to a barn.

description_raw: A Spanish moated and palisaded fort or stronghouse. Destroyed to prevent British use when the garrison was recalled to St. Augustine , FL. The well-preserved site is on private property. Excavated in 1966. Marker erected in 1986. (see also Coweta Blockhouse in GEORGIA)
entry_raw: Apalachicola Fort (1689 - 1691), Holy Trinity - A Spanish moated and palisaded fort or stronghouse. Destroyed to prevent British use when the garrison was recalled to St. Augustine , FL. The well-preserved site is on private property. Excavated in 1966. Marker erected in 1986. (see also Coweta Blockhouse in GEORGIA)

description_raw: A Confederate camp protecting the nearby Bon Secour Saltworks at the mouth of the Bon Secour River. The salt works and the camp were attacked and destroyed by the Union Navy in September 1864. Marker located at 16780 River Road, just west of the intersection with the Bon Secour Highway.
entry_raw: Camp Anderson (1862 - 1864), near Bon Secour - A Confederate camp protecting the nearby Bon Secour Saltworks at the mouth of the Bon Secour River. The salt works and the camp were attacked and destroyed by the Union Navy in September 1864. Marker located at 16780 River Road, just west of the intersection with the Bon Secour Highway.

description_raw: A temporary camp during the Second Creek War.
entry_raw: Camp Balaam (1836), Russell County - A temporary camp during the Second Creek War.

description_raw: A temporary camp of Gen. Andrew Jackson's 4000-man army of Tennessee volunteers and militia in October 1813, after a forced march from Fayetteville , Tennessee, located on the land of Capt. Robert Beaty. The camp site later served as a staging area and supply depot until the end of the First Creek War. The property was sold to John Brahan in 1819. State marker (erected 2012) located at Brahan Spring Park (created 1951), at 3770 Ivy Ave. SW, at 1st Street SW. A related marker ("Andrew Jackson") is located in the Old Town District downtown on Holmes Ave. NE at Lincoln Street NE, which mentions another unnamed camp site of October 1813.
entry_raw: Camp Beaty (1813 - 1814), Huntsville - A temporary camp of Gen. Andrew Jackson's 4000-man army of Tennessee volunteers and militia in October 1813, after a forced march from Fayetteville , Tennessee, located on the land of Capt. Robert Beaty. The camp site later served as a staging area and supply depot until the end of the First Creek War. The property was sold to John Brahan in 1819. State marker (erected 2012) located at Brahan Spring Park (created 1951), at 3770 Ivy Ave. SW, at 1st Street SW. A related marker ("Andrew Jackson") is located in the Old Town District downtown on Holmes Ave. NE at Lincoln Street NE, which mentions another unnamed camp site of October 1813.

description_raw: A Federal muster post and supply depot used during the Cherokee Removals.
entry_raw: Camp Bellefonte (1838), Bellefonte - A Federal muster post and supply depot used during the Cherokee Removals.

description_raw: A Tennessee militia encampment (December 1813 - January 1814). Unknown location.
entry_raw: Camp Carroll (1813 - 1814), Huntsville - A Tennessee militia encampment (December 1813 - January 1814). Unknown location.

description_raw: A Tennessee militia encampment located on the south bank of the Tennessee River (Wheeler Lake), about three miles above James Ditto's Ferry Landing (est. 1807) across from present-day Whitesburg .
entry_raw: Camp Coffee (1813 - 1814), near Laceys Spring - A Tennessee militia encampment located on the south bank of the Tennessee River (Wheeler Lake), about three miles above James Ditto's Ferry Landing (est. 1807) across from present-day Whitesburg .

description_raw: Site located on Calabee Creek, 48 miles from the Chattahoochee River. The GA state militia abandoned and destroyed the original post in 1794. The site was later used again by the GA militia in the 1814 Creek War as a subpost of Fort Hull. The Red Stick Creeks attacked the post in January 1814. Exact location undetermined. (thanks to Marshall Sitrin for additional info)

The site was later used again by the GA militia in the 1814 Creek War as a subpost of Fort Hull. The Red Stick Creeks attacked the post in January 1814. Exact location undetermined. (thanks to Marshall Sitrin for additional info)

description_raw: A Spanish-American War muster-out camp for state troops. Located in the East Lake area.
entry_raw: Camp Falkner (1898), Birmingham - A Spanish-American War muster-out camp for state troops. Located in the East Lake area.

description_raw: A CSA camp of instruction.

description_raw: An American military camp located south of Mobile , used by various Tennessee militia units from November or December 1814, to May 1815. Probably located on the Dog River, possibly near Mann (?).

description_raw: A temporary GA state militia encampment located 15 miles east of Tuskegee .

description_raw: Originally a state National Guard 20-acre summer encampment and hospital east of town, about one-half mile from the Monte Sano resort hotel (built 1887). Also used as an annual summer camp for soldiers from Fort Barrancas, Florida. Also used as a Spanish-American War camp in 1898 by Army Regulars. The hotel closed in 1900, and was later demolished in 1944. Camp marker located on Panorama Drive SE at Monte Sano Blvd. SE.

Also used as an annual summer camp for soldiers from Fort Barrancas, Florida. Also used as a Spanish-American War camp in 1898 by Army Regulars. The hotel closed in 1900, and was later demolished in 1944. Camp marker located on Panorama Drive SE at Monte Sano Blvd. SE.

description_raw: A CSA camp of instruction for the First Alabama State Volunteers of the Mobile Fire Brigade. Located about one mile west of the city on the north side of the road to Spring Hill .
entry_raw: Camp Moore (1861), Mobile - A CSA camp of instruction for the First Alabama State Volunteers of the Mobile Fire Brigade. Located about one mile west of the city on the north side of the road to Spring Hill .

description_raw: A Confederate camp of observation and supply depot along the railroad, established in May 1862 after the evacuation of Pensacola , Florida.
entry_raw: Camp Pollard (1862 - 1865), Pollard - A Confederate camp of observation and supply depot along the railroad, established in May 1862 after the evacuation of Pensacola , Florida.

description_raw: A Spanish-American War winter camp. One of the Army General Hospitals (Leiter ?) from Camp Chickamauga, GA was relocated here in October after the war. Located just west of town, near the old Union Foundry and the American Pipe and Foundry Company. Parades were held on the grounds of the old Anniston Inn, which had become a college by then. West of the present-day Fort McClellan reservation.

description_raw: A Union camp on the grounds of the Green Academy (1812). The Academy buildings were used for Officers' quarters. The school was later burned down in 1864. Marker located at 605 Clinton Ave. East at the present-day East Clinton School (1938) (Providence Classical School since 1996).
entry_raw: Camp Taylor (1862), Huntsville - A Union camp on the grounds of the Green Academy (1812). The Academy buildings were used for Officers' quarters. The school was later burned down in 1864. Marker located at 605 Clinton Ave. East at the present-day East Clinton School (1938) (Providence Classical School since 1996).

description_raw: A Confederate conscription camp and military hospital was located here. The camp was closed in July 1863 after the fall of Vicksburg (MS), but the hospital remained open, along with a cemetery with hundreds of graves. Marker located on Union Camp Road (CR 52) just north of Cooper Lane, about four miles south of town. Site is private property.

The camp was closed in July 1863 after the fall of Vicksburg (MS), but the hospital remained open, along with a cemetery with hundreds of graves. Marker located on Union Camp Road (CR 52) just north of Cooper Lane, about four miles south of town. Site is private property.

description_raw: A Spanish-American War winter camp, later renamed Camp Albert G. Forse . Troops were encamped in various locations throughout the city: the Robinson home at 2709 Meridian Pike; "Oaklawn" (location ?); the Sullivan home on Greene and Randolph Streets; Brahan Spring Park (cavalry) in South Huntsville ; the Moore home (location ?); the Chapman farm (location ?); the Steele home at 808 Maysville Road (general HQ); Moore's Grove (hospital camp); College Grove near Randolph Street; Calhoun Grove; McCalley Grove; and in West Huntsville . The Medical Suppy House headquarters was on Holmes Street.

description_raw: A CSA training camp was established at the Shelby Springs Hotel and Spa (1839). The hotel itself was taken over as a military hospital in 1865. The resort reopened in 1869, but was closed in 1915. The site is now a cattle ranch off of AL 25.
entry_raw: Camp Winn (1862 - 1865), near Shelby - A CSA training camp was established at the Shelby Springs Hotel and Spa (1839). The hotel itself was taken over as a military hospital in 1865. The resort reopened in 1869, but was closed in 1915. The site is now a cattle ranch off of AL 25.

description_raw: A CSA picket post and observation camp (May 1862) for the advanced land defense of Fort Morgan. Abandoned after the fall of Fort Morgan (August 1864). State marker located off of West Fort Morgan Road (AL 180) and Island Club Drive.
entry_raw: Camp Withers (1862 - 1864), Gulf Shores - A CSA picket post and observation camp (May 1862) for the advanced land defense of Fort Morgan. Abandoned after the fall of Fort Morgan (August 1864). State marker located off of West Fort Morgan Road (AL 180) and Island Club Drive.

description_raw: A Union encampment of the First Brigade, Fourth Division, Fifteenth Corps, with about 3000 men, guarding the Memphis and Charleston Railroad and the telegraph lines between Scottsboro and Stevenson . Four regimental camps were set up in January 1864 on either side of the railroad at and within one block of the depot. Most of the troops were withdrawn by May 1864. The town was attacked by Confederate forces in January 1865, the Union garrison then only two regiments of U.S.C.T. infantry, who were eventually driven off by artillery fire. The original depot building (built 1861) is still extant, at East Maple Ave. and North Houston Street.
entry_raw: Camp at Scottsboro (1864 - 1865), Scottsboro - A Union encampment of the First Brigade, Fourth Division, Fifteenth Corps, with about 3000 men, guarding the Memphis and Charleston Railroad and the telegraph lines between Scottsboro and Stevenson . Four regimental camps were set up in January 1864 on either side of the railroad at and within one block of the depot. Most of the troops were withdrawn by May 1864. The town was attacked by Confederate forces in January 1865, the Union garrison then only two regiments of U.S.C.T. infantry, who were eventually driven off by artillery fire. The original depot building (built 1861) is still extant, at East Maple Ave. and North Houston Street.

description_raw: A Federal camp located seven miles northeast of Fort Montgomery, ten miles from the Alabama River, at the old townsite of Montpelier . Also known as Camp Montpelier and Fort Montpelier in different sources.
entry_raw: Cantonment Montpelier (1817 - 1820), near Little River - A Federal camp located seven miles northeast of Fort Montgomery, ten miles from the Alabama River, at the old townsite of Montpelier . Also known as Camp Montpelier and Fort Montpelier in different sources.

description_raw: A Federal troop encampment during the construction/improvement of the Natchez Trace, located at the crossing of the Tennessee River. On which side of the river it was located is unclear. George Colbert's Ferry operated here from 1802 to 1819. Colbert's Stand (inn) was on the south bank of the river.
entry_raw: Cantonment on the Tennessee River (1803 - 1805), near Georgetown - A Federal troop encampment during the construction/improvement of the Natchez Trace, located at the crossing of the Tennessee River. On which side of the river it was located is unclear. George Colbert's Ferry operated here from 1802 to 1819. Colbert's Stand (inn) was on the south bank of the river.

description_raw: A CSA five-gun battery on the Tennessee River at the mouth of Bear Creek. Located at the old townsite of Chickasaw , now submerged under Pickwick Lake.
entry_raw: Chickasaw Battery (1861 - 1862 or 1863), near Riverton - A CSA five-gun battery on the Tennessee River at the mouth of Bear Creek. Located at the old townsite of Chickasaw , now submerged under Pickwick Lake.

description_raw: The Chickasaw Indian Agency was located here after it was moved from Pontotoc , Mississippi in 1825, and was in use until the removal of the Chickasaw Nation from Alabama and Mississippi in 1837. Located north of town near the Tennessee River, upriver from (southeast of) Georgetown . The settlement here was renamed Newport in 1837. State marker located on Mulberry Lane (County Road 27), 0.4 mile east of Moody Lane (County Road 25).
entry_raw: Chickasaw Indian Agency (1825 - 1837), near Cherokee - The Chickasaw Indian Agency was located here after it was moved from Pontotoc , Mississippi in 1825, and was in use until the removal of the Chickasaw Nation from Alabama and Mississippi in 1837. Located north of town near the Tennessee River, upriver from (southeast of) Georgetown . The settlement here was renamed Newport in 1837. State marker located on Mulberry Lane (County Road 27), 0.4 mile east of Moody Lane (County Road 25).

description_raw: About 3000 Union troops were garrisoned here by early 1864. There were three unnamed redoubts with blockhouses; Fort #1 was on a hill downriver (south) from the railroad bridge. Fort #2 was on a hill overlooking the steamboat landing on the Tennessee River; Fort #3 was just to the west covering the railroad spur. Three blockhouses protected the two railroad bridges over Long Island; two on either end of the first (west) bridge from town (with 130 men), and the other was on a hill in town overlooking the first (west) bridge.
entry_raw: Civil War Defenses of Bridgeport (1862 - 1865), Bridgeport - About 3000 Union troops were garrisoned here by early 1864. There were three unnamed redoubts with blockhouses; Fort #1 was on a hill downriver (south) from the railroad bridge. Fort #2 was on a hill overlooking the steamboat landing on the Tennessee River; Fort #3 was just to the west covering the railroad spur. Three blockhouses protected the two railroad bridges over Long Island; two on either end of the first (west) bridge from town (with 130 men), and the other was on a hill in town overlooking the first (west) bridge.

name_primary: Civil War Defenses of Columbus, GA
description_raw: Confederate breastworks and rifle pits from 1865 are still visible by the Chattahoochee River on the north side of town, used in the defense of Columbus , Georgia. Earthwork batteries were also erected on Red Hill in 1865, now the west lawn of the Russell County Courthouse (marker erected in 2004). Another marker (1988) also designates the preserved site of CSA three-gun Fort #5 (1863 - 1865) near the river, a moated 90-foot pentagon. Total number and wherabouts of other numbered works undetermined. The town was originally named Girard during the Civil War. See also Battle of Columbus from Explore Southern History.com
entry_raw: Civil War Defenses of Columbus, GA (1863 - 1865), Phenix City - Confederate breastworks and rifle pits from 1865 are still visible by the Chattahoochee River on the north side of town, used in the defense of Columbus , Georgia. Earthwork batteries were also erected on Red Hill in 1865, now the west lawn of the Russell County Courthouse (marker erected in 2004). Another marker (1988) also designates the preserved site of CSA three-gun Fort #5 (1863 - 1865) near the river, a moated 90-foot pentagon. Total number and wherabouts of other numbered works undetermined. The town was originally named Girard during the Civil War. See also Battle of Columbus from Explore Southern History.com

description_raw: A line of uncompleted entrenchments and breastworks surrounded the city as the Union army advanced in April 1865.
entry_raw: Civil War Defenses of Montgomery (1865), Montgomery - A line of uncompleted entrenchments and breastworks surrounded the city as the Union army advanced in April 1865.

description_raw: The city was surrounded by a ring of earthworks (mainly infantry parapets and rifle pits), from the west-side of Beech Creek to the east-side of Valley Creek, with 24 numbered batteries for 77 field guns. An inner line of four heavy earthwork batteries was never completed. The city was captured by the Union in April 1865. "Redoubt #15" marker located at 423 Battery Ave. at Summerfield Road (still here in 2023). "Union Troops Charge" marker once located nearby at 520 Highland Ave. (US 80) at Summerfield Road (removed 2015). "Interior Redoubt III" marker once located at 1164 Lapsley Street, near Buckeye Ave. (removed 2015). "Last Stronghold Falls" marker once located at 1007 Broad Street (US 80 Business) at Voeglin Ave. (removed 2022).
entry_raw: Civil War Defenses of Selma (1862 - 1865), Selma - The city was surrounded by a ring of earthworks (mainly infantry parapets and rifle pits), from the west-side of Beech Creek to the east-side of Valley Creek, with 24 numbered batteries for 77 field guns. An inner line of four heavy earthwork batteries was never completed. The city was captured by the Union in April 1865. "Redoubt #15" marker located at 423 Battery Ave. at Summerfield Road (still here in 2023). "Union Troops Charge" marker once located nearby at 520 Highland Ave. (US 80) at Summerfield Road (removed 2015). "Interior Redoubt III" marker once located at 1164 Lapsley Street, near Buckeye Ave. (removed 2015). "Last Stronghold Falls" marker once located at 1007 Broad Street (US 80 Business) at Voeglin Ave. (removed 2022).

description_raw: CSA Fort Stevenson (1861) was the original town defense. Union works in 1862 included: Fort (Redoubt) Harker , a rectangular 50-yard square earthwork (seven guns) with a powder magazine and a bombproof, on the south side of town on Crow Creek. The earthworks and four gun platforms are well-preserved. Excavated in 1976, restored in 1985. Now a town park on Sawmill Road overlooking Guntersville Lake. Fort (Redoubt) Mitchel (2) , on the railroad north of the depot. Two unfinished redoubts, southeast and northeast of town. There were seven numbered blockhouses surrounding the town on all sides. Another blockhouse (20 men) was dedicated to protecting the N & C Railroad bridge over an unnamed creek about one mile east of town, near New Town .
entry_raw: Civil War Defenses of Stevenson (1861 - 1865), Stevenson - CSA Fort Stevenson (1861) was the original town defense. Union works in 1862 included: Fort (Redoubt) Harker , a rectangular 50-yard square earthwork (seven guns) with a powder magazine and a bombproof, on the south side of town on Crow Creek. The earthworks and four gun platforms are well-preserved. Excavated in 1976, restored in 1985. Now a town park on Sawmill Road overlooking Guntersville Lake. Fort (Redoubt) Mitchel (2) , on the railroad north of the depot. Two unfinished redoubts, southeast and northeast of town. There were seven numbered blockhouses surrounding the town on all sides. Another blockhouse (20 men) was dedicated to protecting the N & C Railroad bridge over an unnamed creek about one mile east of town, near New Town .

description_raw: A Confederate defense of the Alabama - Tennessee River Railroad bridge over the Coosa River northeast of town. Built in February 1865 and manned by a reserve company of mostly old men and boys, the post was captured by the Union in March 1865. The railroad trestle over Yellow Leaf Creek , just to the west of the Coosa River bridge, was also defended by two works on either side of the creek, and also manned by old men and boys, and were also captured by the Union in the same raid. A state marker describing all three unnamed forts is located on Alabama State Highway 25 at the entrance to the Alabama Power Gaston Steam Plant (National Carbon Capture Center).
entry_raw: Coosa River Fort (1865), near Wilsonville - A Confederate defense of the Alabama - Tennessee River Railroad bridge over the Coosa River northeast of town. Built in February 1865 and manned by a reserve company of mostly old men and boys, the post was captured by the Union in March 1865. The railroad trestle over Yellow Leaf Creek , just to the west of the Coosa River bridge, was also defended by two works on either side of the creek, and also manned by old men and boys, and were also captured by the Union in the same raid. A state marker describing all three unnamed forts is located on Alabama State Highway 25 at the entrance to the Alabama Power Gaston Steam Plant (National Carbon Capture Center).

description_raw: Union engineers constructed seven blockhouses, some possibly with added stockades or redoubts, at the major bridges and trestles on the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad along Crow Creek between Anderson , Tennessee and Stevenson , Alabama. There were 160 men in total garrisoned between all seven blockhouses to guard this stretch of the rail line.
entry_raw: Crow Creek Blockhouses (1864 - 1865), Jackson County - Union engineers constructed seven blockhouses, some possibly with added stockades or redoubts, at the major bridges and trestles on the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad along Crow Creek between Anderson , Tennessee and Stevenson , Alabama. There were 160 men in total garrisoned between all seven blockhouses to guard this stretch of the rail line.

description_raw: A settlers' fort located about four miles south of town on the Tombigbee River.
entry_raw: Curry's Fort (1813), near Jackson - A settlers' fort located about four miles south of town on the Tombigbee River.

description_raw: An unnamed Union redoubt with several supporting batteries and earthworks was located along the railroad to the bridge over the Tennessee River. Confederates attacked the town in 1864. Markers for the Union defense line are located at the Old State Bank Building on Bank Street, at Bank and Vine Streets, and at Railroad and Lafayette Streets. A Union advanced lunette was located at Moulton Street and 6th Ave. (no marker). A CSA advanced battery was located at Moulton Street and 10th Ave. (no marker).
entry_raw: Decatur Fort (1862 - 1865), Decatur - An unnamed Union redoubt with several supporting batteries and earthworks was located along the railroad to the bridge over the Tennessee River. Confederates attacked the town in 1864. Markers for the Union defense line are located at the Old State Bank Building on Bank Street, at Bank and Vine Streets, and at Railroad and Lafayette Streets. A Union advanced lunette was located at Moulton Street and 6th Ave. (no marker). A CSA advanced battery was located at Moulton Street and 10th Ave. (no marker).

description_raw: A three-acre settlers' stockaded fort located on Wood's Bluff on the Tombigbee River at Cunningham Bend, about 100 yards above the bluff landing, in Section 11, Township 11, Range 1 west. Evacuated after the Fort Mims massacre and left abandoned.
entry_raw: Easley's Fort (1813), Woods Bluff - A three-acre settlers' stockaded fort located on Wood's Bluff on the Tombigbee River at Cunningham Bend, about 100 yards above the bluff landing, in Section 11, Township 11, Range 1 west. Evacuated after the Fort Mims massacre and left abandoned.

description_raw: Site of Confederate breastworks in Monumental Park at South Chestnut and Parkway. At "Bounds Place" on Cypress Mill Road, there is a secret basement with loopholes in the walls, said to have been used by Confederate troops.
entry_raw: Florence Earthworks (1863), Florence - Site of Confederate breastworks in Monumental Park at South Chestnut and Parkway. At "Bounds Place" on Cypress Mill Road, there is a secret basement with loopholes in the walls, said to have been used by Confederate troops.

alt_names: Leslie's Station, Leslie's Post, Fort Lashley,|Lashley's Fort
description_raw: A Lower Creek Indian fortified house or blockhouse, also called Leslie's Station, Leslie's Post, Fort Lashley, and Lashley's Fort (mis-spellings, but apparently pronounced that way). These pro-American Indians were opposed to the Red Sticks, the Creek faction that was causing trouble with the white settlers and General Andrew Jackson's troops, and were besieged by them for several days here. General Jackson defeated the Red Stick Creeks at the "Battle of Talladega" in November 1813. Site located at Fort Lashley Ave. and South Street.
entry_raw: Fort (Alexander) Leslie (1813), Talladega - A Lower Creek Indian fortified house or blockhouse, also called Leslie's Station, Leslie's Post, Fort Lashley, and Lashley's Fort (mis-spellings, but apparently pronounced that way). These pro-American Indians were opposed to the Red Sticks, the Creek faction that was causing trouble with the white settlers and General Andrew Jackson's troops, and were besieged by them for several days here. General Jackson defeated the Red Stick Creeks at the "Battle of Talladega" in November 1813. Site located at Fort Lashley Ave. and South Street.

description_raw: A settlers' fort located six miles from Fort Autrey. Possibly also known as Fort Belleville .
entry_raw: Fort (John) Bell (1817), Belleville - A settlers' fort located six miles from Fort Autrey. Possibly also known as Fort Belleville .

description_raw: A GA state militia (Carolina Brigade) fort and supply post in Macon County 17 miles southeast of Tuskegee . The Lewis Tavern was later built here.
entry_raw: Fort Bainbridge (1814), near Hurtsboro - A GA state militia (Carolina Brigade) fort and supply post in Macon County 17 miles southeast of Tuskegee . The Lewis Tavern was later built here.

description_raw: An earthwork constructed by the local residents for their own defense, it had no official recognition by the CSA government. No action is known to have taken place here.

description_raw: The Spanish originally had a battery and small garrison posted here in 1806. The Americans later built a 17-gun sand-walled fort here in 1813 (April or May), using the guns from Fort Charlotte (Cond) in Mobile . The British unsuccessfully attacked the fort in September 1814. It was then later briefly captured by the British in February 1815 just days after their defeat at New Orleans . Fort Morgan (see below) was built in the near vicinity beginning in 1818, the presumed exact site of Fort Bowyer is now washed away and underwater just to the north (or northwest) of Fort Morgan's ramparts.
entry_raw: Fort Bowyer (1806 - unknown, 1813 - 1816), Mobile Point - The Spanish originally had a battery and small garrison posted here in 1806. The Americans later built a 17-gun sand-walled fort here in 1813 (April or May), using the guns from Fort Charlotte (Cond) in Mobile . The British unsuccessfully attacked the fort in September 1814. It was then later briefly captured by the British in February 1815 just days after their defeat at New Orleans . Fort Morgan (see below) was built in the near vicinity beginning in 1818, the presumed exact site of Fort Bowyer is now washed away and underwater just to the north (or northwest) of Fort Morgan's ramparts.

description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort also used by the local militia.
entry_raw: Fort Browder (1836), Barbour County - A settlers' stockaded fort also used by the local militia.

NOTE: The "Battle of Burnt Corn" (July 1813) was actually fought near Appleton along Burnt Corn Creek in present-day Escambia County. (thanks to Steve Stacey for providing correct location)

description_raw: A temporary Federal post during the First Creek War, located on Weatherford Bluff (Alabama Heights) on the Alabama River at Limestone Creek. It was a stockaded enclosure 200-feet square with three blockhouses and a crescent-shaped earthwork battery. The post was later used as a settler refuge until 1818. State marker on US 84 at CR 39 (Lera Landeggal Highway).

State marker on US 84 at CR 39 (Lera Landeggal Highway).

description_raw: A state militia fort. Hobdy's Bridge , about 8 miles from Williams . The troops were dispatched to deal with them. (thanks to Marshall Sitrin for additional info) -->

description_raw: A settlers' 16-by-30-foot log fort to protect against the Red Stick Creek Indians. Remnants still exist. A marker (1978) locates the site on County Road 55.
entry_raw: Fort Cusseta (1836), Cusseta - A settlers' 16-by-30-foot log fort to protect against the Red Stick Creek Indians. Remnants still exist. A marker (1978) locates the site on County Road 55.

description_raw: A Territorial Militia fort built by Col. Sam Dale (April 1818), located five miles north of Greenville , built in response to settler complaints about high protection fees imposed by Thomas Gary at his private fort, about two miles west. Became the Butler County seat in 1819 until 1821.
entry_raw: Fort Dale (1818), Fort Dale - A Territorial Militia fort built by Col. Became the Butler County seat in 1819 until 1821.

description_raw: A militia fort built by the Carolina Brigade, located on a bluff along the Tallapoosa River. Tennessee hero John Sevier died here in 1815 while surveying the GA-AL border, and was originally buried here. His grave was moved to Knoxville , TN in 1888. Located on the opposite bank of the river was Fort Burrows , which protected the ferry and military communications on the west side of the river towards Fort Jackson.

description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort for protection against the Creeks. The town of Jonesborough was first settled in 1815, and was later incorporated into the city of Bessemer . Site located at the Terrace Manor housing complex. (thanks to Jim Bennett for providing location)
entry_raw: Fort Jonesborough (1813), Bessemer - A settlers' stockaded fort for protection against the Creeks. description_raw: A Federal log stockade near " Turkey Town ", used for the Cherokee Removals on the "Trail of Tears". Probably located on what is now Williamson Island in Weiss Lake (Coosa River). No remains.
entry_raw: Fort Lovell (1838), near Cedar Bluff - A Federal log stockade near " Turkey Town ", used for the Cherokee Removals on the "Trail of Tears". Probably located on what is now Williamson Island in Weiss Lake (Coosa River). No remains.

description_raw: This was a place of refuge for settlers after the Fort Mims Massacre. It was a 60-yard square log post stockade with trenches, located about 4.5 miles south and 1.5 miles west of Suggsville , in Section 1, Township 6, Range 3 east. Built by the GA state militia just before the massacre. Just 225 yards south of here was Fort (Zachariah) Glass (1813), a settlers' fort garrisoned by state troops. Together they held over 1000 settlers.

description_raw: A Federal fort located two miles from Fort Mims, opposite the Alabama River "cutoff". Rebuilt in 1817, including a new hospital.
entry_raw: Fort Montgomery (1814 - 1818), near Tensaw - A Federal fort located two miles from Fort Mims, opposite the Alabama River "cutoff". Rebuilt in 1817, including a new hospital.

entry_raw: Fort Opelika (1865), Opelika - A CSA earthwork fort that was unfinished at the end of the war.

alt_names: Grant's Island Battery|Fort Grant|Tower at Pass aux Herons
description_raw: A Confederate coastal defense (six-gun earthwork, no remains) located on a sandbar (Grant's Island) on the north side of Grant's Pass near Heron Island, built to close off the western entrance to Mobile Bay. Originally built in July 1861 as a three-gun battery known as Grant's Island Battery , or Fort Grant , abandoned in May 1862, rearmed in December 1862, renamed in October 1863, and rebuilt and enlarged in April 1864. The Confederates destroyed it before evacuating in August 1864, after failing to stop the Union Navy from forcing their way past Forts Morgan and Gaines during the Battle of Mobile Bay. Union troops occupied the island thereafter, but the fort was never rebuilt. A hurricane in 1906 demolished most of what was left of the island. The modern pier at Cedar Point offers an excellent viewing overlook. A Third System coastal defense, Tower at Pass aux Herons , a circular two-level 26-gun casemated Martello tower, was planned and designed for Tower Island on the south side of Grant's Pass after 1857, and money was finally appropriated by Congress in September 1860, but no work was ever begun due to the outbreak of the Civil War.
entry_raw: Fort Powell (1861 - 1864), Grant's Island - A Confederate coastal defense (six-gun earthwork, no remains) located on a sandbar (Grant's Island) on the north side of Grant's Pass near Heron Island, built to close off the western entrance to Mobile Bay. Originally built in July 1861 as a three-gun battery known as Grant's Island Battery , or Fort Grant , abandoned in May 1862, rearmed in December 1862, renamed in October 1863, and rebuilt and enlarged in April 1864. The Confederates destroyed it before evacuating in August 1864, after failing to stop the Union Navy from forcing their way past Forts Morgan and Gaines during the Battle of Mobile Bay. Union troops occupied the island thereafter, but the fort was never rebuilt. A hurricane in 1906 demolished most of what was left of the island. The modern pier at Cedar Point offers an excellent viewing overlook. A Third System coastal defense, Tower at Pass aux Herons , a circular two-level 26-gun casemated Martello tower, was planned and designed for Tower Island on the south side of Grant's Pass after 1857, and money was finally appropriated by Congress in September 1860, but no work was ever begun due to the outbreak of the Civil War.

description_raw: A Spanish outpost near the entrance to Baha de Filipina (Mobile Bay) built by an exploratory group from the Luna colony at Santa Mara de Ochuse ( Pensacola , FL). The Achuse Indian village of 1539 (as noted by the DeSoto Expedition) was located here, now the site of the present-day Shell Banks Baptist Church (at 12125 State Highway 180).
entry_raw: Fort Serof (1559 - 1560), Gasque - A Spanish outpost near the entrance to Baha de Filipina (Mobile Bay) built by an exploratory group from the Luna colony at Santa Mara de Ochuse ( Pensacola , FL). The Achuse Indian village of 1539 (as noted by the DeSoto Expedition) was located here, now the site of the present-day Shell Banks Baptist Church (at 12125 State Highway 180).

description_raw: A Federal post that was erected at Mount Vernon Landing at Ward's Bluff soon after the Spanish vacated the northern portion of West Florida (that portion above the 31st Parallel). It was stockaded with four corner blockhouses. Aaron Burr was held here in 1807 after his arrest for treason. At one time (pre Civil War) the site was reserved as a subpost of Mount Vernon Arsenal. Also spelled Stodderd in some historical sources. The name of the town was later altered from the original spelling. The modern public boat landing and adjacent parking lot have obliterated most of the historic site.
entry_raw: Fort Stoddert (1799 - 1814), Fort Stoddard - A Federal post that was erected at Mount Vernon Landing at Ward's Bluff soon after the Spanish vacated the northern portion of West Florida (that portion above the 31st Parallel). It was stockaded with four corner blockhouses. Aaron Burr was held here in 1807 after his arrest for treason. At one time (pre Civil War) the site was reserved as a subpost of Mount Vernon Arsenal. Also spelled Stodderd in some historical sources. The name of the town was later altered from the original spelling. The modern public boat landing and adjacent parking lot have obliterated most of the historic site.

description_raw: A CSA heavy-gun river defense on the Alabama River, east of Carlton . Built to prevent Union gunboats from ascending the river further inland. Constructed in the fall of 1862 as Choctaw Bluff Battery , formally named in June 1863. Not abandoned until after the fall of Mobile in April 1865, when its magazines were blown up by the garrison.
entry_raw: Fort Stonewall (1862 - 1865), Choctaw Bluff - A CSA heavy-gun river defense on the Alabama River, east of Carlton . Built to prevent Union gunboats from ascending the river further inland. Constructed in the fall of 1862 as Choctaw Bluff Battery , formally named in June 1863. Not abandoned until after the fall of Mobile in April 1865, when its magazines were blown up by the garrison.

description_raw: General Andrew Jackson's base of operations during the First Creek War. Located four miles west of town on the Coosa River opposite Charchee Creek. The palisaded fort was 100 yards square enclosing eight hospital huts, a supply house, and 25 tents, as well as a large hog pen. Built after the Battle of Tallassahatchee, and before the Battle of Talladega. A stone marker (1913) was erected by the D.A.R..
entry_raw: Fort Strother (1813 - 1814), near Ohatchee - General Andrew Jackson's base of operations during the First Creek War. Located four miles west of town on the Coosa River opposite Charchee Creek. The palisaded fort was 100 yards square enclosing eight hospital huts, a supply house, and 25 tents, as well as a large hog pen. Built after the Battle of Tallassahatchee, and before the Battle of Talladega. A stone marker (1913) was erected by the D.A.R..

description_raw: A Federal supply post and hospital, roughly halfway between Fort Strother and Fort Jackson. Located on the Coosa River at Cedar Creek. Site is now under the waters of the Coosa River created by the Mitchell Dam. A state marker is located about 12 miles east in Sylacauga , on Fort Williams Street.
entry_raw: Fort Williams (1814), near Talladega Springs - A Federal supply post and hospital, roughly halfway between Fort Strother and Fort Jackson. Located on the Coosa River at Cedar Creek. Site is now under the waters of the Coosa River created by the Mitchell Dam. A state marker is located about 12 miles east in Sylacauga , on Fort Williams Street.

entry_raw: Landrum's Fort (1813), near Chilton - A settlers' stockaded fort on the west bank of Satilpa Creek, near "Good Springs", located 11 miles west of Fort Sinquefield, in Section 18, Township 8, Range 2 East. Nearby was another settlers' fort called Mott's Fort (1813).

entry_raw: Lawson Lavier's Fort (1813), near Suggsville - A settlers' stockaded fort located southeast of town on the Alabama River. Abandoned for Fort Madison after the attack on Fort Sinquefield.

description_raw: A Late Mississippian Period small but heavily palisaded Indian village was probably located here on the lower Cahawba River, although the exact site is undetermined. Visited by Hernando DeSoto in October 1540. The Spanish were ambushed here by the natives, having lost 22 men and seven horses. About 2500 natives were subsequently killed in the "Battle of Mabila". The Spanish then stayed here about one month before burning the village and moving on.
entry_raw: Mabila (1400 - 1540), near Old Cahawba ? - A Late Mississippian Period small but heavily palisaded Indian village was probably located here on the lower Cahawba River, although the exact site is undetermined. Visited by Hernando DeSoto in October 1540. The Spanish were ambushed here by the natives, having lost 22 men and seven horses. About 2500 natives were subsequently killed in the "Battle of Mabila". The Spanish then stayed here about one month before burning the village and moving on.

William and John McGrew, former British Loyalists from the eastern states who settled here at "McGrew's Reserve" during the Spanish regime. The fort was also garrisoned by the territorial militia.
entry_raw: McGrew's Fort (1813), near Salitpa - A settlers' two-acre palisaded fort in Section 1, Township 7, Range 1 west. Built by brothers (Col.) William and John McGrew, former British Loyalists from the eastern states who settled here at "McGrew's Reserve" during the Spanish regime. The fort was also garrisoned by the territorial militia.

It is owned by the US Army Corps of Engineers as part of the Jones Bluff Dam Project, leased to the city for public park use.

description_raw: A British stockaded trading post on the west bank of the Tallapoosa River, opposite Sandy Creek, near the Upper Creek (Red Stick) village of Okfuskee , that tried to compete with the French at Fort Toulouse. It lasted only a few years, as the Upper Creeks were generally hostile to the British. Also spelled Okfuski . The actual site, 12 miles west of Dadeville , is now under the waters of Martin Lake. A state marker is located on the north side of US 280 at Sweet Circle, west of Peckerwood Road, near Jacksons Gap , about six miles east of the fort site.
entry_raw: Okfuskee Fort (1735 - 1740 ?), near Alexander City - A British stockaded trading post on the west bank of the Tallapoosa River, opposite Sandy Creek, near the Upper Creek (Red Stick) village of Okfuskee , that tried to compete with the French at Fort Toulouse. It lasted only a few years, as the Upper Creeks were generally hostile to the British. Also spelled Okfuski . The actual site, 12 miles west of Dadeville , is now under the waters of Martin Lake. A state marker is located on the north side of US 280 at Sweet Circle, west of Peckerwood Road, near Jacksons Gap , about six miles east of the fort site.

description_raw: FORT WIKI Built by the Spanish after retaking the area from the British. Attacked by the British in 1781. Rebuilt in 1799. A series of CSA works were later built here in 1864, the old Spanish work became Redoubt #1 (see below) .
entry_raw: Old Spanish Fort (1780 - unknown, 1864 - 1865), Spanish Fort - FORT WIKI Built by the Spanish after retaking the area from the British. Attacked by the British in 1781. Rebuilt in 1799. A series of CSA works were later built here in 1864, the old Spanish work became Redoubt #1 (see below) .

description_raw: A settlers' fortified saw and grist mill complex on Pine Log Creek, about two miles southeast of Fort Mims, built by brothers John and William Peirce, garrisoned by the local militia. The stockade included three strong blockhouses. Abandoned for Fort Stoddert after the massacre at Fort Mims. Regarrisoned with Federal troops in December 1813 (aka Fort Pierce ). ( NOTE: the Peirce brothers spelled their name with "ei", however several contemporary sources have it spelled with "ie".)
entry_raw: Peirce's Mill Fort (1813), Tensaw - A settlers' fortified saw and grist mill complex on Pine Log Creek, about two miles southeast of Fort Mims, built by brothers John and William Peirce, garrisoned by the local militia. The stockade included three strong blockhouses. Abandoned for Fort Stoddert after the massacre at Fort Mims. Regarrisoned with Federal troops in December 1813 (aka Fort Pierce ). ( NOTE: the Peirce brothers spelled their name with "ei", however several contemporary sources have it spelled with "ie".)

description_raw: A settlers' saw mill complex on the Tensaw River just south of town, briefly occupied and fortified (stockaded) by Territorial Militia under Major John Hinson, it was evacuated by them and then burned by Creek Indians after the Fort Mims Massacre (August 1813). The mill was under government contract to provide lumber for construction and repairs at Fort Charlotte and Fort Bowyer.
entry_raw: Post at Kennedy's Mills (1813), near Stockton - A settlers' saw mill complex on the Tensaw River just south of town, briefly occupied and fortified (stockaded) by Territorial Militia under Major John Hinson, it was evacuated by them and then burned by Creek Indians after the Fort Mims Massacre (August 1813). The mill was under government contract to provide lumber for construction and repairs at Fort Charlotte and Fort Bowyer.

description_raw: A settlers' large stockaded fort located west of the Tombigbee River, possibly on Mill Creek.
entry_raw: Rankin's Fort (1813), near Millry - A settlers' large stockaded fort located west of the Tombigbee River, possibly on Mill Creek.

description_raw: A short-lived Spanish settlement (February-June 1560) organized under the Luna Expedition to Ochuse ( Pensacola , FL), located on the Alabama River at a former Mobile Indian village site ( Nanipacana ). Between 800-1000 Spanish colonists, including women, soldiers, priests, and Mexican Indians, traveled four or five days north from Pensacola Bay. It was planned to be fortified with four gates, with 140 town lots around a central plaza with a church and monastery, and a separate compound for the Royal Governor's House and arms storehouse. It was abandoned after several months due to heavy rains and short supplies of food and clothing, and the lack of cooperation from the local Mobile Indians, and the settlers returned to Pensacola Bay and eventually back to Cuba. It is not known how much of the planned town was actually built, or its exact location. A 1939 stone monument on US 84 at Claiborne marks the site of the old Indian village of Piache (visited by DeSoto in 1540), and also claims that Nanipacana was also near here. It also may have possibly been located further north near Yellow Bluff .
entry_raw: Santa Cruz de Nanipacana (1560), near Perdue Hill ? - A short-lived Spanish settlement (February-June 1560) organized under the Luna Expedition to Ochuse ( Pensacola , FL), located on the Alabama River at a former Mobile Indian village site ( Nanipacana ). Between 800-1000 Spanish colonists, including women, soldiers, priests, and Mexican Indians, traveled four or five days north from Pensacola Bay. It was planned to be fortified with four gates, with 140 town lots around a central plaza with a church and monastery, and a separate compound for the Royal Governor's House and arms storehouse. It was abandoned after several months due to heavy rains and short supplies of food and clothing, and the lack of cooperation from the local Mobile Indians, and the settlers returned to Pensacola Bay and eventually back to Cuba. It is not known how much of the planned town was actually built, or its exact location. A 1939 stone monument on US 84 at Claiborne marks the site of the old Indian village of Piache (visited by DeSoto in 1540), and also claims that Nanipacana was also near here. It also may have possibly been located further north near Yellow Bluff .

alt_names: Camp Clark|Camp Joseph F. Johnston|Camp Coppinger|Camp Mobile|Camp Spring Hill
description_raw: Camp Clark , a muster camp for state troops. Located at "Alba's Pasture", midway between Frascati and Monroe Park on the bay shore. Site now on or near the state docks. Camp Joseph F. Johnston , a muster camp for state troops, located adjacent to or near Camp Clark. Camp Coppinger , located in the Crichton area, bounded by Three Mile Creek to the north, Stein's Creek to the south, and Moffatt Road (US 98) to the west. Also known as Camp Mobile . Probably the same as Camp Spring Hill . Mobile was a secondary Port of Embarkation after Tampa , FL in 1898.
entry_raw: Spanish-American War Camps of Mobile (1898), Mobile - Camp Clark , a muster camp for state troops. Located at "Alba's Pasture", midway between Frascati and Monroe Park on the bay shore. Site now on or near the state docks. Camp Joseph F. Johnston , a muster camp for state troops, located adjacent to or near Camp Clark. Camp Coppinger , located in the Crichton area, bounded by Three Mile Creek to the north, Stein's Creek to the south, and Moffatt Road (US 98) to the west. Also known as Camp Mobile . Probably the same as Camp Spring Hill . Mobile was a secondary Port of Embarkation after Tampa , FL in 1898.

description_raw: A Confederate States Armory was located at the Tallassee Manufacturing Company mill (1844) on the Tallapoosa River in the spring (June) of 1864 with the transfer of men and machinery from the Richmond (VA) Carbine Factory, in operation until April 1865, to produce the new .58-caliber carbine for the Confederate Army. The factory was forced to shut down after the Selma Arsenal was attacked and destroyed by the Union in April 1865, with the machinery and 500 completed carbines hauled away to Cowles Ferry for shipment by rail to Macon , Georgia. The carbines were ultimately never used in battle. The Tallassee Armory was the only Confederate armory not destroyed during the war. The stone ruins of the mill still exist on the west side of the Thurlow Reservoir Dam (no public access). Markers located at 102 James Street at Barnett Blvd., and on Barnett Blvd. (AL 14) at Outer Drive.
entry_raw: Tallassee CSA Armory (1864 - 1865), Tallassee - A Confederate States Armory was located at the Tallassee Manufacturing Company mill (1844) on the Tallapoosa River in the spring (June) of 1864 with the transfer of men and machinery from the Richmond (VA) Carbine Factory, in operation until April 1865, to produce the new .58-caliber carbine for the Confederate Army. The stone ruins of the mill still exist on the west side of the Thurlow Reservoir Dam (no public access). description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort or blockhouse located about two miles west of where Fort Dale was later built. After the Ogly-Stroud Massacre (March 1818) at Poplar Springs, Gary built his fort, but charged a "protection fee" for the nearby settlers, who then demanded from the government another fort for their protection. Gary's Fort was abandoned soon after Fort Dale was completed. State marker located on Sherling Lake Road (County Road 44) north of Ridge Road (County Road 54).

description_raw: Two large palisaded Indian villages, about half a Spanish league apart, visited by the remnants of the DeSoto Expedition in December 1542. The Spanish occupied one village for winter quarters, and tore down the other to build additional houses and seven keelboats. The Spanish finally left in July 1543 in their boats down the Mississippi River, not arriving in Veracruz , Mexico until September 1543.

description_raw: A Confederate encampment and barracks on the west side of the White River near Lowell . The timber was contracted from Peter Van Winkle, who operated the War Eagle Mill in Van Hollow (now within Hobbs State Park ) (marker located on the west-side of the White River bridge on AR 12). The mill was destroyed in March 1862, and Van Winkle fled to Texas until after the war. It is uncertain if the camp was completed, as Van Winkle never received payment for the lumber. See also Arkansas Historic Preservation Program

alt_names: Post at Sulphur Fork|Caddo Indian Agency|Red River Indian Agency
description_raw: A Federal garrison (one company (50 men) of the U.S. 7th Infantry Regiment) protecting a nearby government Indian trading post, or Factory, located on a bluff (Factory Bluff) on the Red River just below the mouth of the Sulphur Fork. Also and originally known as Post at Sulphur Fork from 1819 to 1821, then garrisoned by detachments of the U.S. 1st Infantry Regiment. The Sulphur Fork Trading Factory (or Caddo Indian Agency ) (aka Red River Indian Agency ) was in operation here from 1818 to 1823. Afterwards it became a civilian trading post until the site was abandoned in November 1825 and relocated south to present-day Caddo Parish, Louisiana. Site was excavated in 1988. See also Arkansas Archaeological Society
entry_raw: Cantonment Taylor (1821 - 1825), near Doddridge - A Federal garrison (one company (50 men) of the U.S. 7th Infantry Regiment) protecting a nearby government Indian trading post, or Factory, located on a bluff (Factory Bluff) on the Red River just below the mouth of the Sulphur Fork. Afterwards it became a civilian trading post until the site was abandoned in November 1825 and relocated south to present-day Caddo Parish, Louisiana. Site was excavated in 1988. alt_names: Fort Lookout|Fort Pickett|Redoubt B|Fort Diamond|Redoubt E|Fort Southerland|Redoubt D|Tate's Bluff Fort|Water Battery|Camden CSA Ordnance Works
description_raw: The Confederates built a series of five earthwork defenses to defend the town. They were unmanned when Union forces captured the town in April 1864 during the Red River Campaign. After the Union troops left, the forts were regarrisoned for the duration of the war. Fort Lookout is located on private property on Van Buren Road, on the south bank of the Ouachita River about one mile west of US 79. Fort Pickett was located in the Greenwood Cemetery on Maul Road. Also known as Redoubt B . No remains. Traces of earthworks still remain off Gravel Pit Road. Fort Diamond is located on Bradley Ferry Road. Also known as Redoubt E . It was marked in error for years as Fort Southerland , but the markers were corrected in 2006. Fort Southerland was located on California Street near Center Street. Also known as Redoubt D . No remains. Tate's Bluff Fort (1864), built by the CSA after the town was reoccupied, located on a bluff overlooking the Ouachita and Little Missouri Rivers. Site marked in 2010. Water Battery (1864) built by CSA troops on the Ouachita River at Sandy Beach. Site marked in 2007. Camden CSA Ordnance Works (1862 - 1863) produced munitions until the foundry equipment was transferred to Shreveport , Louisiana in May 1863. Of interest in town at 926 Washington Street is the 1847 McCollum-Chidester House (admission fee), which was used as Union headquarters during their brief occupation of the town.

Fort Lookout is located on private property on Van Buren Road, on the south bank of the Ouachita River about one mile west of US 79. Fort Pickett was located in the Greenwood Cemetery on Maul Road. Also known as Redoubt B . No remains. Traces of earthworks still remain off Gravel Pit Road. Fort Diamond is located on Bradley Ferry Road. Also known as Redoubt E . It was marked in error for years as Fort Southerland , but the markers were corrected in 2006. Fort Southerland was located on California Street near Center Street. Also known as Redoubt D . Water Battery (1864) built by CSA troops on the Ouachita River at Sandy Beach. Site marked in 2007. Camden CSA Ordnance Works (1862 - 1863) produced munitions until the foundry equipment was transferred to Shreveport , Louisiana in May 1863. Of interest in town at 926 Washington Street is the 1847 McCollum-Chidester House (admission fee), which was used as Union headquarters during their brief occupation of the town.

name_primary: Civil War Defenses of Little Rock
description_raw: Four CSA works protected the eastern approaches to Little Rock in advance of the Union army; one located at Woodruff's Mill; another on the Arkansas River directly across from the present-day airport; one along the Memphis and Little Rock Railroad south of Ink Bayou; and one at a road junction between Ink Bayou and Five Mile Creek. CSA Camp Crystal Hill was located on Crystal Hill, northwest of present-day Burns Park (near the I-40 and I-430 interchange).
entry_raw: Civil War Defenses of Little Rock (1863), North Little Rock - Four CSA works protected the eastern approaches to Little Rock in advance of the Union army; one located at Woodruff's Mill; another on the Arkansas River directly across from the present-day airport; one along the Memphis and Little Rock Railroad south of Ink Bayou; and one at a road junction between Ink Bayou and Five Mile Creek. CSA Camp Crystal Hill was located on Crystal Hill, northwest of present-day Burns Park (near the I-40 and I-430 interchange).

name_primary: Civil War Defenses of the City of Fort Smith
description_raw: The Union occupied the city and built a series of blockhouses and artillery positions and rifle pits in a ring around the city. Blockhouse No. 4 (four guns, 500 men) was located at the corner of North 5th Street and H Street, which covered the approach from Van Buren . Blockhouse No. 2 was located on a hill near South 10th Street and "O" Street, which covered the Texas Road (Towson Ave.). Confederate forces attacked the city in July 1864. A marker for the Massard Prairie Battlefield (July 1864) is located on Red Pine Drive.

description_raw: A French settlers' trading post. This was briefly the political center of the new Ouachita District of Louisiana under the Spanish regime ( Post of Ouachita ), from its founding in 1783 until the post was relocated in 1785 to present-day Monroe , Louisiana. The present town of Camden , permanently settled in 1824, was originally named Ecore a Fabre (Fabre's Bluffs) after the first settler.

description_raw: Built by the Spanish after being forced out of Fort Barrancas in present-day Memphis , TN by the Americans. The settlement around the fort later came to be called Hopefield . The town was burned during the Civil War, and the river has since washed away all traces of the town and old fort.
