description_raw: A fur trading post established by David Faribault, son of Jean Baptiste Faribault. Also known as Elk River Post .
entry_raw: David Faribault's Post (1846), Elk River - A fur trading post established by David Faribault, son of Jean Baptiste Faribault. Also known as Elk River Post .

description_raw: A Columbia Fur Co. trading post. Undetermined exact location.
entry_raw: Fort Adams (1826), Lac qui Parle Lake - A Columbia Fur Co. trading post. Undetermined exact location.

description_raw: A Columbia Fur Co. trading post located on Leaf Lake, east of Otter Tail Lake.
entry_raw: Fort Bolivar (1826), Leaf Lake - A Columbia Fur Co. trading post located on Leaf Lake, east of Otter Tail Lake.

description_raw: A French fur trade post located two miles north of town along the Mississippi River. The 80 by 120-foot ruins were discovered in 1983.
entry_raw: Fort Duquesne (1752 - 1754), Little Falls - A French fur trade post located two miles north of town along the Mississippi River. The 80 by 120-foot ruins were discovered in 1983.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post located "on the River au Gris of the St. Peters below Big Stone Lake", which was likely the Yellow Bank River.
entry_raw: Fort Greene (1826), near Odessa - An American Fur Co. post located "on the River au Gris of the St. Peters below Big Stone Lake", which was likely the Yellow Bank River.

description_raw: A French post established by Pierre Charles Le Sueur for fur trading and mining copper. Also known as Fort Vert . It consisted of a stockade around three or four cabins. Le Sueur left for France in 1701, but several men stayed behind until forced to abandon the post due to Indian hostility. The presumed site is located on a 70-foot high natural mound at the Minnesota and Blue Earth Rivers, now farmland. No trace currently exists of the fort. A marker is located on MN 66 just south of town.
entry_raw: Fort L'Huillier (1700 - 1702), near Mankato - A French post established by Pierre Charles Le Sueur for fur trading and mining copper. Also known as Fort Vert . It consisted of a stockade around three or four cabins. Le Sueur left for France in 1701, but several men stayed behind until forced to abandon the post due to Indian hostility. The presumed site is located on a 70-foot high natural mound at the Minnesota and Blue Earth Rivers, now farmland. No trace currently exists of the fort. A marker is located on MN 66 just south of town.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. trading post located at the "Little Rapids" of the Minnesota (St. Peter's) River, established and operated by Jean Baptiste Faribault, father to Oliver, David, and Alexander. Marker on Chaska Blvd. just west of town. Marker denotes 1824 date, most histories give 1826 date. The North West Company earlier operated Little Rapids Post (1804), located just south of Carver . Jean Faribault was here at that time as a trader for the Nor'westers.
entry_raw: Fort Lewis (1824 or 1826), near Chaska - An American Fur Co. trading post located at the "Little Rapids" of the Minnesota (St. Peter's) River, established and operated by Jean Baptiste Faribault, father to Oliver, David, and Alexander. Marker on Chaska Blvd. just west of town. Marker denotes 1824 date, most histories give 1826 date. The North West Company earlier operated Little Rapids Post (1804), located just south of Carver . Jean Faribault was here at that time as a trader for the Nor'westers.

description_raw: A log fort built by Nicolas Perrot. Briefly abandoned due to Indian hostilities. Apparently later known as Fort Bon Secours , as shown on a 1700 French map. It was erroneously depicted as the site of Fort Le Sueur (2) on a 1703 French map, in reference to Fort Le Sueur (1) which was actually at Prairie Island.
entry_raw: Fort Perrot (1683 - 1687, 1689 - unknown), near Wabasha - A log fort built by Nicolas Perrot. Briefly abandoned due to Indian hostilities. Apparently later known as Fort Bon Secours , as shown on a 1700 French map. It was erroneously depicted as the site of Fort Le Sueur (2) on a 1703 French map, in reference to Fort Le Sueur (1) which was actually at Prairie Island.

description_raw: A Columbia Fur Co. trading post located near the southern end of the lake. Taken over by the American Fur Co. in 1827 and closed.
entry_raw: Fort Washington (1823 - 1827), Lake Traverse - A Columbia Fur Co. trading post located near the southern end of the lake. Taken over by the American Fur Co. in 1827 and closed.

description_raw: A fur trading post at the "Grand Rapids" of the Mississippi River.
entry_raw: Franois Gaisson's Post (1789), Sauk Rapids - A fur trading post at the "Grand Rapids" of the Mississippi River.

description_raw: A trading post operated here or nearby for at least one winter.
entry_raw: Grand Marais Post (1823 - 1824), Grand Marais - A trading post operated here or nearby for at least one winter.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post operated by Joseph LaFramboise (Jr.), located at the "Grande Lisire" (Great Oasis), overlooking Tibbetts Lake, about eight miles due west of Lake Shetek. Abandoned in the fall of 1837, it was burned down in 1838 by Indians. Remnants of the log stockade were reported to still stand in 1866 when the land was settled by brothers John and Bartlett Low.
entry_raw: Great Oasis Post (1834 - 1837), Lowville Township, Murray County - An American Fur Co. post operated by Joseph LaFramboise (Jr.), located at the "Grande Lisire" (Great Oasis), overlooking Tibbetts Lake, about eight miles due west of Lake Shetek. Abandoned in the fall of 1837, it was burned down in 1838 by Indians. Remnants of the log stockade were reported to still stand in 1866 when the land was settled by brothers John and Bartlett Low.

description_raw: Several different civilian trading posts were established here. Joseph Brown settled here in 1838, and later built another post on the island after Hazen Mooers and Andrew Robertson built log huts in 1839.
entry_raw: Grey Cloud Island Trading Posts (1836 - 1839), Grey Cloud Island - Several different civilian trading posts were established here. Joseph Brown settled here in 1838, and later built another post on the island after Hazen Mooers and Andrew Robertson built log huts in 1839.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post located at Gull Lake. Still operating in 1836. Exact location undetermined. Benjamin Baker (independent) was trading here without a license in 1828.
entry_raw: Gull Lake Post (1823 - 1830's), Gull Lake - An American Fur Co. post located at Gull Lake. Still operating in 1836. Exact location undetermined. Benjamin Baker (independent) was trading here without a license in 1828.

description_raw: A trading post located about two miles above the mouth of the Groundhouse River (on the Groundhouse River ?, or on the Snake River ?).
entry_raw: Henry Rust's Post (1845 ?), near Brunswick, Kanabec County - A trading post located about two miles above the mouth of the Groundhouse River (on the Groundhouse River ?, or on the Snake River ?).

description_raw: A trader's wintering post. Undetermined location.
entry_raw: James Lockwood's Post (1816 - 1817), Lac qui Parle Lake - A trader's wintering post. Undetermined location.

description_raw: A fur trade post originally located on the Redwood River in Section 5 of Lyons Township . Lynd later moved to Section 33 of Lynd Township .
entry_raw: James Lynd's Post (1855 - 1857), near Lynd - A fur trade post originally located on the Redwood River in Section 5 of Lyons Township . Lynd later moved to Section 33 of Lynd Township .

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post located on the Roseau River two miles above (east of) Roseau Lake.
entry_raw: Jerome Semat's Post (1821 - 1840), near Roseau - An American Fur Co. post located on the Roseau River two miles above (east of) Roseau Lake.

description_raw: A North West Co. trade post located on the Snake River ("Rivire aux Marais"), an outpost of the Pembina Settlement in present North Dakota.
entry_raw: John Cameron's Post (1803), near Fork, or Big Woods - A North West Co. trade post located on the Snake River ("Rivire aux Marais"), an outpost of the Pembina Settlement in present North Dakota.

description_raw: An independent British trader's wintering post may have been located in this vicinity.
entry_raw: Jonathan Carver's House (1766 - 1767), near Traverse ? - An independent British trader's wintering post may have been located in this vicinity.

description_raw: A 1785 British trade post was located on the east side of the lake. In 1832 an American trade post was located on the west shore at present-day Bemidji .
entry_raw: Lake Bemidji Posts (1785, 1832), Lake Bemidji - A 1785 British trade post was located on the east side of the lake. In 1832 an American trade post was located on the west shore at present-day Bemidji .

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post on the Des Moines River, in the southwest corner of present-day Cottonwood County.
entry_raw: Lake Talcot Post (1835), Talcot Lake - An American Fur Co. post on the Des Moines River, in the southwest corner of present-day Cottonwood County.

description_raw: Originally a North West Co. trade post ( Winnibigoshish House ) was located here. An American trading post (1834 - 1848) was later located on Bowen's Point near Cut Foot Sioux Lake. A marker here mistakenly identifies the post to the Hudson's Bay Co.. The American Fur Co. also had a post (1823 - 1830's) on the north shore at the mouth of the Pigeon River. Another trading post (date ?) was located on the western shore between the Mississippi River inlet and Sugar Lake (the NWC post ? or another ?).
entry_raw: Lake Winnibigoshish Posts (1798, 1823, 1834), Lake Winnibigoshish - Originally a North West Co. trade post ( Winnibigoshish House ) was located here. An American trading post (1834 - 1848) was later located on Bowen's Point near Cut Foot Sioux Lake. A marker here mistakenly identifies the post to the Hudson's Bay Co.. The American Fur Co. also had a post (1823 - 1830's) on the north shore at the mouth of the Pigeon River. Another trading post (date ?) was located on the western shore between the Mississippi River inlet and Sugar Lake (the NWC post ? or another ?).

description_raw: A Columbia Fur Co. / American Fur Co. trading post located on the Minnesota River about one mile upriver (southwest) from Fort Snelling. Joseph Brown operated the post in 1831. Site is now the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport.
entry_raw: Land's End Post (1831), Minneapolis - A Columbia Fur Co. / American Fur Co. trading post located on the Minnesota River about one mile upriver (southwest) from Fort Snelling. Joseph Brown operated the post in 1831. Site is now the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport.

alt_names: Jean Baptiste Cadotte's Post|Joseph Reaume's Post|Prescott's Post
description_raw: Various trading posts were located along the Leaf River at various times: Jean Baptiste Cadotte's Post (1790's), Joseph Reaume's Post (1792), and Prescott's Post (date ?), at undetermined exact locations. An American Fur Co. post was also on the Leaf River around 1830.
entry_raw: Leaf River Posts (1790's, 1830), near Central, Wadena County - Various trading posts were located along the Leaf River at various times: Jean Baptiste Cadotte's Post (1790's), Joseph Reaume's Post (1792), and Prescott's Post (date ?), at undetermined exact locations. An American Fur Co. post was also on the Leaf River around 1830.

description_raw: A North West Co. post was located on Otter Tail Point in 1785. Another North West Co. post was located further west about 1805. The second post was the scene of Lt. Zebulon Pike's stopover in February 1806 during his expedition to find the source of the Mississippi River (which was actually at Lake Itasca further west), where the British flag was ordered taken down and temporarily replaced by the American flag ( Pike's Fort (2) ). The international boundary here was not finally settled until 1818. The American Fur Co. had a post on Pine Point in 1833. An opposition company trade post, under William Johnston, was near the Pine Point post. Another American Fur Co. post (date ?) was located on Oak Point. Another trade post (1830's ?) was shown on the eastern shore of the lake.
entry_raw: Leech Lake Posts (1785 - 1818 ?, 1833), Leech Lake - A North West Co. post was located on Otter Tail Point in 1785. Another North West Co. post was located further west about 1805. The second post was the scene of Lt. Zebulon Pike's stopover in February 1806 during his expedition to find the source of the Mississippi River (which was actually at Lake Itasca further west), where the British flag was ordered taken down and temporarily replaced by the American flag ( Pike's Fort (2) ). The international boundary here was not finally settled until 1818. The American Fur Co. had a post on Pine Point in 1833. An opposition company trade post, under William Johnston, was near the Pine Point post. Another American Fur Co. post (date ?) was located on Oak Point. Another trade post (1830's ?) was shown on the eastern shore of the lake.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post at or near the mouth of Little Rock Creek on the Minnesota River, west of town. Operated by Joseph LaFramboise (Jr.) until 1834. Hazen Mooers relocated here and took over in 1835.
entry_raw: Little Rock Post (1832 - unknown), near Saint George - An American Fur Co. post at or near the mouth of Little Rock Creek on the Minnesota River, west of town. Operated by Joseph LaFramboise (Jr.) until 1834. Hazen Mooers relocated here and took over in 1835.

description_raw: A French post is shown on a 1750 map at the mouth of the Vermilion River. French traders Bourassa and Eustache, under the command of Pierre La Vrendrye, built and manned this temporary post. It was likely still operating into the 1750's. The North West Co. later had a post here in 1807-08, and was still shown here in 1820. Possibly located across the present-day international border in Ontario.
entry_raw: Little Vermilion Lake Posts (1736 - 1750's, 1807 - 1820 ?), near Crane Lake - A French post is shown on a 1750 map at the mouth of the Vermilion River. French traders Bourassa and Eustache, under the command of Pierre La Vrendrye, built and manned this temporary post. It was likely still operating into the 1750's. The North West Co. later had a post here in 1807-08, and was still shown here in 1820. Possibly located across the present-day international border in Ontario.

description_raw: A North West Co. post (winter 1794-95) was located on the west shore of the Lower Red Lake, about two miles south of the Red Lake River outflow. A Hudson's Bay Co. post, Red Lake House (1795), was established on the southern shore near Redby and the Mud River. Another North West Co. post (1790) was located on the eastern shore near the Battle River. An American Fur Co. post was later established on the eastern side of the lake in 1826. Another post was built in 1848 between this post and the mission station nearby. John Cameron may have opened another N.W.Co. post here during the early 1800's.
entry_raw: Lower Red Lake Posts (1790, 1795, 1826, 1848), Lower Red Lake - A North West Co. post (winter 1794-95) was located on the west shore of the Lower Red Lake, about two miles south of the Red Lake River outflow. A Hudson's Bay Co. post, Red Lake House (1795), was established on the southern shore near Redby and the Mud River. Another North West Co. post (1790) was located on the eastern shore near the Battle River. An American Fur Co. post was later established on the eastern side of the lake in 1826. Another post was built in 1848 between this post and the mission station nearby. John Cameron may have opened another N.W.Co. post here during the early 1800's.

description_raw: At least four traders had posts here in 1862: William Forbes, Franois (Francis) LaBathe (2), Louis Robert , and Nathan Myrick . In the Sioux attack of August 1862, LaBathe was killed at his post. Andrew Myrick (Nathan's brother), S.B. Garvie (Myrick's partner), and James Lynd were killed at Myrick's Post. Joseph Belland was killed at Forbes' Post. Others were also killed. William Forbes, Louis Robert, and Nathan Myrick were not present at the time of the attack. All four posts were destroyed.
entry_raw: Lower Sioux Agency Trading Posts (1862), near Redwood Falls - At least four traders had posts here in 1862: William Forbes, Franois (Francis) LaBathe (2), Louis Robert , and Nathan Myrick . In the Sioux attack of August 1862, LaBathe was killed at his post. Andrew Myrick (Nathan's brother), S.B. Garvie (Myrick's partner), and James Lynd were killed at Myrick's Post. Joseph Belland was killed at Forbes' Post. Others were also killed. William Forbes, Louis Robert, and Nathan Myrick were not present at the time of the attack. All four posts were destroyed.

description_raw: A fur trading post established by Maurice Samuels, located on the west bank of the St. Croix River near Sunrise Island, just below the mouth of the Sunrise River. Also known as Sunrise River Post . Consisted mainly of a single house and barn. Site excavated by the National Park Service.
entry_raw: Maurice Samuels' Post (1846), Sunrise - A fur trading post established by Maurice Samuels, located on the west bank of the St. Croix River near Sunrise Island, just below the mouth of the Sunrise River. Also known as Sunrise River Post . Consisted mainly of a single house and barn. Site excavated by the National Park Service.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post located on the south bank of the Minnesota River across from Fort Snelling. A stone warehouse was built in 1836.
entry_raw: Mendota Post (1820's - 1845 ?), Mendota - An American Fur Co. post located on the south bank of the Minnesota River across from Fort Snelling. A stone warehouse was built in 1836.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post located on the northeast shore of the lake.
entry_raw: Mille Lacs Lake Post (1820), near Malmo - An American Fur Co. post located on the northeast shore of the lake.

description_raw: An independent American fur trade post by a Cleveland, OH firm. Located along the Pigeon River near Moose Mountain. The Hudson's Bay Co. afterwards (1850's) had a post on this lake ( Lac d'Orignal Post (1) ), presumably on the Canadian side (see also) .
entry_raw: Moose Lake Posts (1844), Moose Lake - An independent American fur trade post by a Cleveland, OH firm. Located along the Pigeon River near Moose Mountain. The Hudson's Bay Co. afterwards (1850's) had a post on this lake ( Lac d'Orignal Post (1) ), presumably on the Canadian side (see also) .

description_raw: An independent trading post operated by Joseph Brown. Site located at 2nd and Vermillion Streets. The town was originally named Oliver's Grove , after U.S. Army Lt. William Oliver, who had a wintering supply camp here in 1819-20 when the river froze. Brown was also present then.
entry_raw: Oliver's Grove Post (1832 - 1834), Hastings - An independent trading post operated by Joseph Brown. Site located at 2nd and Vermillion Streets. The town was originally named Oliver's Grove , after U.S. Army Lt. William Oliver, who had a wintering supply camp here in 1819-20 when the river froze. Brown was also present then.

description_raw: Several trading posts were once located here, around the northeastern shore of the lake at the portage between the Otter Tail River (at Otter Tail Lake) and the Leaf River (at Leaf Lake). An American Fur Co. post was here until 1836. Another post was here in 1850 - 1860.
entry_raw: Otter Tail Lake Posts (1830's - 1860), near Ottertail - Several trading posts were once located here, around the northeastern shore of the lake at the portage between the Otter Tail River (at Otter Tail Lake) and the Leaf River (at Leaf Lake). An American Fur Co. post was here until 1836. Another post was here in 1850 - 1860.

description_raw: A North West Co. trading post, on the eastern shore of the lake at the inlet of the Bowstring River.
entry_raw: Patchatchanban Post (1785), Bowstring Lake - A North West Co. trading post, on the eastern shore of the lake at the inlet of the Bowstring River.

description_raw: A Hudson's Bay Co. trading post was located here on the east bank of the Red River, opposite the mouth of the Pembina River, for a short time before it was re-established on the west bank of the Red River in 1803. (see also Pembina House , NORTH DAKOTA page 1)
entry_raw: Pembina House (1801 - 1802 ?), St. Vincent - A Hudson's Bay Co. trading post was located here on the east bank of the Red River, opposite the mouth of the Pembina River, for a short time before it was re-established on the west bank of the Red River in 1803. (see also Pembina House , NORTH DAKOTA page 1)

description_raw: A North West Co. trading post located on the east side of the Red River, above (south of) the mouth of the Pembina River. Shown on a 1791 British map, and said to have been the first North West Co. post on the Red River. Abandoned before 1798.
entry_raw: Peter Grant's House (Fort) (1791 - 1794 ? or 1796 ?), near St. Vincent - A North West Co. trading post located on the east side of the Red River, above (south of) the mouth of the Pembina River. Shown on a 1791 British map, and said to have been the first North West Co. post on the Red River. Abandoned before 1798.

description_raw: A stockaded trading post built and operated by Allen Wilmot, Thomas Anderson, and Joseph Rolette. In 1818 Jean Baptiste Faribault opened a post here.
entry_raw: Pike's Island Posts (1810 - 1812 ?, 1818), Saint Paul - A stockaded trading post built and operated by Allen Wilmot, Thomas Anderson, and Joseph Rolette. In 1818 Jean Baptiste Faribault opened a post here.

description_raw: A trade post on the Pine River, mentioned in 1784 and 1789. Undetermined exact location.
entry_raw: Pine River Fort (1784, 1789), near Mission - A trade post on the Pine River, mentioned in 1784 and 1789. Undetermined exact location.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post located at the head of the Platte River, in the southeast corner of present-day Crow Wing County.
entry_raw: Platte Lake Post (1831), Platte Lake - An American Fur Co. post located at the head of the Platte River, in the southeast corner of present-day Crow Wing County.

description_raw: A North West Co. post located at the portage between the Prairie River (at Prairie Lake) and the St. Louis River (at Mirbat Creek ?), south of present-day Gowan .
entry_raw: Prairie Portage Post (1785), Prairie Lake - A North West Co. post located at the portage between the Prairie River (at Prairie Lake) and the St. Louis River (at Mirbat Creek ?), south of present-day Gowan .

description_raw: An American Fur Co. trading post located on the Rainy River below Rainy Lake, just above (upstream from) Chaudire/Koochiching Falls. Also known as Isle House . Also known as Bouy's Post (?).
entry_raw: Rainy Lake Post (1822 - 1833), International Falls - An American Fur Co. trading post located on the Rainy River below Rainy Lake, just above (upstream from) Chaudire/Koochiching Falls. Also known as Isle House . Also known as Bouy's Post (?).

description_raw: A North West Co. post was noted on the present-day Minnesota-side of the Rainy River at Lake of the Woods. The HBC's Hungry Hall Post (1825) was located opposite on the Canadian side of the river (see also) .
entry_raw: Rainy River Post (1794 - 1820 ?), near Wheelers Point - A North West Co. post was noted on the present-day Minnesota-side of the Rainy River at Lake of the Woods. The HBC's Hungry Hall Post (1825) was located opposite on the Canadian side of the river (see also) .

description_raw: A North West Co. trade post, operated by Jean Baptiste Cadotte. Located on the east side of the mouth of the Clearwater River.
entry_raw: Red Lake River Post (1798), Red Lake Falls - A North West Co. trade post, operated by Jean Baptiste Cadotte. Located on the east side of the mouth of the Clearwater River.

description_raw: A winter post of William Morrison at "Lac La Folle" (Lower Rice Lake).
entry_raw: Rice Lake Post (1803 - 1804), Rice Lake, Clearwater County - A winter post of William Morrison at "Lac La Folle" (Lower Rice Lake).

description_raw: A trading post established by Charles Patterson at Patterson's Rapids on the Minnesota River, near Sacred Heart Creek. Also known as Charles Patterson's Post . The Sioux gave him the nickname "Sacred Hat Man" for the bearskin hat that he wore. The name was later corrupted to "Sacred Heart".
entry_raw: Sacred Heart Post (1783), Sacred Heart Township, Renville County - A trading post established by Charles Patterson at Patterson's Rapids on the Minnesota River, near Sacred Heart Creek. Also known as Charles Patterson's Post . The Sioux gave him the nickname "Sacred Hat Man" for the bearskin hat that he wore. The name was later corrupted to "Sacred Heart".

description_raw: A North West Co. trading post was originally here. The American Fur Co. operated another post here, almost due south of the NWC post, from 1823, under William Aitken, and was still shown here on an 1866 map as Roussain's Post . Located on the south shore of the lake, possibly near Pike Bay.
entry_raw: Vermilion Lake Posts (1793 - unknown, 1823 - 1866), near Tower ?, Vermillion Lake - A North West Co. trading post was originally here. The American Fur Co. operated another post here, almost due south of the NWC post, from 1823, under William Aitken, and was still shown here on an 1866 map as Roussain's Post . Located on the south shore of the lake, possibly near Pike Bay.

description_raw: An independent or North West Co. (?) trading post located at the confluence of the Thief and Red Lake Rivers.
entry_raw: Vincent Roy's Post (1794), Thief River Falls - An independent or North West Co. (?) trading post located at the confluence of the Thief and Red Lake Rivers.

alt_names: Augustin Rocque's (Sr.) Post (1)|Augustin Rocque's (Jr.) Post (2)|Edward Hudson's Post|Charles Read's Post
description_raw: Site of several trading posts, including Augustin Rocque's (Sr.) Post (1) (1810 - 1825/30), Augustin Rocque's (Jr.) Post (2) (1835 - 1860), Edward Hudson's Post (1840 - 1845), Charles Read's Post (1847 - unknown), and several others from 1840 - 1860. Alexis Bailly traded at Wabasha after leaving Mendota . Joseph LaBathe had a post there in 1840. Augustin Rocque (Sr.) was apparently located at present-day Read's Landing as early as the 1770's during the American Revolution. Augustin Rocque (Jr.) apparently had his original post just west of present-day Read's Landing , then relocated to the Beef Slough.
entry_raw: Wabasha Trading Posts (1810 - 1860), Read's Landing, Wabasha - Site of several trading posts, including Augustin Rocque's (Sr.) Post (1) (1810 - 1825/30), Augustin Rocque's (Jr.) Post (2) (1835 - 1860), Edward Hudson's Post (1840 - 1845), Charles Read's Post (1847 - unknown), and several others from 1840 - 1860. Alexis Bailly traded at Wabasha after leaving Mendota . Joseph LaBathe had a post there in 1840. Augustin Rocque (Sr.) was apparently located at present-day Read's Landing as early as the 1770's during the American Revolution. Augustin Rocque (Jr.) apparently had his original post just west of present-day Read's Landing , then relocated to the Beef Slough.

description_raw: A trading post located on the west side of the Crow Wing River between the Leaf and Partridge Rivers.
entry_raw: Wadena Post (1850's), near Central, Wadena County - A trading post located on the west side of the Crow Wing River between the Leaf and Partridge Rivers.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. post.
entry_raw: Warroad Post (1820 - unknown), Warroad - An American Fur Co. post.

description_raw: A fur trade post located two and one-half miles north of the mouth of the Watab River, north of Sartell .
entry_raw: Watab Post (1844 - 1855), near Watab - A fur trade post located two and one-half miles north of the mouth of the Watab River, north of Sartell .

description_raw: A trading post, possibly operated by the American Fur Co., located on "Point des Sables". The American Fur Co. did have a post here earlier in 1830 (name undetermined).
entry_raw: Wells' Trading Post (1839), Frontenac - A trading post, possibly operated by the American Fur Co., located on "Point des Sables". The American Fur Co. did have a post here earlier in 1830 (name undetermined).

location_text: White Oak Lake, near Deer River
description_raw: Three unnamed independent (?) French-Canadian fur traders had posts at or near White Oak Point at White Oak Lake, as reported in 1791.
entry_raw: White Oak Lake Posts (1791), White Oak Lake, near Deer River - Three unnamed independent (?) French-Canadian fur traders had posts at or near White Oak Point at White Oak Lake, as reported in 1791.

description_raw: The North West Co. had two posts here, one in ruins and another still occupied in 1806. An American Fur Co. post was here later around 1830. Undetermined exact locations.
entry_raw: Whitefish Lake Posts (1806, 1830), Whitefish Lake - The North West Co. had two posts here, one in ruins and another still occupied in 1806. An American Fur Co. post was here later around 1830. Undetermined exact locations.

description_raw: An independent trading post in Morrison County.
entry_raw: William Aitken's Post (1850), Gregory - An independent trading post in Morrison County.

description_raw: A civilian post (single log cabin) operated by brothers Charles, William, and George Wood. Indians attacked the settlement (originally named Springfield ) in 1857, killing Charles and William. The settlement was then abandoned for several years.
entry_raw: Wood's Trading Post (1856 - 1857), Jackson - A civilian post (single log cabin) operated by brothers Charles, William, and George Wood. Indians attacked the settlement (originally named Springfield ) in 1857, killing Charles and William. The settlement was then abandoned for several years.

description_raw: An unnamed Union horseshoe-shaped earthwork located one mile southwest of town, within the Deer Run State Forest (Current River Conservation Area) on a ridge overlooking Jakie Hollow. Built in late winter or early spring by the 13th Illinois Cavalry and/or the 25th Missouri Infantry to protect the approach to the town on the old military trail from Van Buren through the Logan Creek Valley. No action is known to have occured here, and the town was abandoned as a garrisoned post after five months. The extant earthwork was discovered and documented in 1996-98. The town was formerly named Barnesville until sometime after 1868.
entry_raw: Barnesville Fort (1863), Ellington - An unnamed Union horseshoe-shaped earthwork located one mile southwest of town, within the Deer Run State Forest (Current River Conservation Area) on a ridge overlooking Jakie Hollow. Built in late winter or early spring by the 13th Illinois Cavalry and/or the 25th Missouri Infantry to protect the approach to the town on the old military trail from Van Buren through the Logan Creek Valley. No action is known to have occured here, and the town was abandoned as a garrisoned post after five months. The extant earthwork was discovered and documented in 1996-98. The town was formerly named Barnesville until sometime after 1868.

description_raw: A Union infantry and artillery earthwork protecting the terminus of the Cairo and Fulton Railroad near the old townsite of Ohio City . The post surrounded the Bird Farm, and included a magazine, headquarters, hospital, guardhouse, and quartermaster stores. During the war much of the site was eroded away by the Mississippi River, and the works were moved and enlarged several times. Much of the original site has since eroded away again. Union Camp Lyon (1861) was here or nearby.
entry_raw: Bird's Point Fort (1861 - 1865), Bird's Point - A Union infantry and artillery earthwork protecting the terminus of the Cairo and Fulton Railroad near the old townsite of Ohio City . The post surrounded the Bird Farm, and included a magazine, headquarters, hospital, guardhouse, and quartermaster stores. During the war much of the site was eroded away by the Mississippi River, and the works were moved and enlarged several times. Much of the original site has since eroded away again. Union Camp Lyon (1861) was here or nearby.

description_raw: An unnamed Confederate fort or gun battery located on a hill on the eastern side of town. The town was occupied by the Union in November 1861. Site now the Stoddard County Civil War Cemetery on Route E.
entry_raw: Bloomfield Fort (1861), Bloomfield - An unnamed Confederate fort or gun battery located on a hill on the eastern side of town. The town was occupied by the Union in November 1861. Site now the Stoddard County Civil War Cemetery on Route E.

description_raw: A settlers' fort in the Boone's Lick region.
entry_raw: Buckhart's Fort (1812 - 1815), near Arrow Rock - A settlers' fort in the Boone's Lick region.

description_raw: A settlers' fort located two miles southwest of town on Buffalo Creek. Built by the Missouri Rangers, it was abandoned and burned in March 1813.
entry_raw: Buffalo Fort (1812 - 1813), Louisiana - A settlers' fort located two miles southwest of town on Buffalo Creek. Built by the Missouri Rangers, it was abandoned and burned in March 1813.

description_raw: Either a local militia fort built by the Missouri Rangers under 2nd Lt. James Callaway, OR a settlers' two-story log fort built by Flanders Callaway, father of James.
entry_raw: Callaway's Fort (1812 - 1815), Marthasville - Either a local militia fort built by the Missouri Rangers under 2nd Lt. James Callaway, OR a settlers' two-story log fort built by Flanders Callaway, father of James.

description_raw: A Union camp established northeast of town after the Pea Ridge campaign. Camp Bliss Spring and Camp Bliss Hollow were so named after the war.
entry_raw: Camp Bliss (1862 - 1863), near McDowell - A Union camp established northeast of town after the Pea Ridge campaign. Camp Bliss Spring and Camp Bliss Hollow were so named after the war.

description_raw: A Confederate recruitment camp located on North Indian Creek, about five miles south of Newtonia .
entry_raw: Camp Coffee (1862), near Wanda - A Confederate recruitment camp located on North Indian Creek, about five miles south of Newtonia .

description_raw: Union breastworks once located on the hill where the present-day city water tower now stands.
entry_raw: Camp Defiance (1862 - 1865), Cassville - Union breastworks once located on the hill where the present-day city water tower now stands.

description_raw: A temporary state guard mobilzation center for engineer units. In operation only one month. Located at the Chain of Rocks Water Works.
entry_raw: Camp Gaillard (1917), St. Louis - A temporary state guard mobilzation center for engineer units. In operation only one month. Located at the Chain of Rocks Water Works.

description_raw: A temporary Federal encampment.
entry_raw: Camp Gamble (1849), St. Louis - A temporary Federal encampment.

description_raw: A state militia encampment during the so-called "Honey War" border dispute between Missouri and Iowa. It was located at the old town site of Waterloo , on the Fox River near town. The Iowa militia had an encampment on the Des Moines River at Farmington , IA (see also) . The dispute was settled in Iowa's favor, without bloodshed.
entry_raw: Camp Hard Times (1839), near Chambersburg - A state militia encampment during the so-called "Honey War" border dispute between Missouri and Iowa. It was located at the old town site of Waterloo , on the Fox River near town. The Iowa militia had an encampment on the Des Moines River at Farmington , IA (see also) . The dispute was settled in Iowa's favor, without bloodshed.

description_raw: A Union training and muster camp.
entry_raw: Camp Krekel (1861), Cottleville - A Union training and muster camp.

description_raw: A Union camp and fortified town. captured by the Confederates in 1863.
entry_raw: Camp Ozark (1862 - 1863), Ozark - A Union camp and fortified town. captured by the Confederates in 1863.

description_raw: A large Union recruitment camp established in June 1862 south of town at or near "Brights Spring" on Flat Creek. In use until the summer of 1863.
entry_raw: Camp Schofield (1862 - 1863), near McDowell - A large Union recruitment camp established in June 1862 south of town at or near "Brights Spring" on Flat Creek. In use until the summer of 1863.

description_raw: A Confederate recruitment and training camp located west of town, near County Road 317.
entry_raw: Camp Spring Hill (1861), near Bell City - A Confederate recruitment and training camp located west of town, near County Road 317.

description_raw: A Union camp located at the fairgrounds.
entry_raw: Camp Tipton (1861), Tipton - A Union camp located at the fairgrounds.

description_raw: A Confederate camp.
entry_raw: Camp Vest (1861), Boonville - A Confederate camp.

description_raw: A French trading post was originally here in 1733, built by Jean Girardot, the site of which is now at Cape Rock Park. Next came a Spanish military post in 1793, built by French trader Louis Lorimier, called Lorimont Post or Red House , located at the future site of Old St. Vincent's Church (1853). Lorimier died here in 1812. The settlement, however, continued to be known as Cape Girardeau . The Red House Interpretive Center is located at 128 South Main Street (admission fee).
entry_raw: Cape Girardot Trading Posts (1733 - unknown, 1793 - 1808 ?), Cape Girardeau - A French trading post was originally here in 1733, built by Jean Girardot, the site of which is now at Cape Rock Park. Next came a Spanish military post in 1793, built by French trader Louis Lorimier, called Lorimont Post or Red House , located at the future site of Old St. Vincent's Church (1853). Lorimier died here in 1812. The settlement, however, continued to be known as Cape Girardeau . The Red House Interpretive Center is located at 128 South Main Street (admission fee).

description_raw: A settlers' fort located two miles south of the Cuivre River on Dog (or Big) Prairie, about two miles from Fort Howard. Attacked by Indians, killing 12 soldiers. They are buried in town.
entry_raw: Captain White's Fort (1812 - unknown), near Old Monroe - A settlers' fort located two miles south of the Cuivre River on Dog (or Big) Prairie, about two miles from Fort Howard. Attacked by Indians, killing 12 soldiers. They are buried in town.

description_raw: Fort Wyman (1861 - 1865), one of two Union forts, in addition to a one-mile radius of earthworks and trenches that surrounded the town. The fort was 400 feet square, rectangular with a moat, composed of slanted timbers on the outer walls, located one mile south of town on a hill along US 63. Some remains on private property at the Wyman School. Over 20,000 troops were garrisoned in the town. Marker located at 262 North Main Street at the Old Phelps County Courthouse (1860). See also History of Rolla in the Civil War Fort Dette (1863 - 1865), a Union cross-shaped fort on the north-side of town. Also spelled Detty . Site located on the campus of the University of Missouri-Rolla. No remains. Camp Carey Gratz (1861 - 1865), a Union camp located near town. It became for a time the Headquarters, Army of the West.
entry_raw: Civil War Defenses of Rolla (1861 - 1865), Rolla - Fort Wyman (1861 - 1865), one of two Union forts, in addition to a one-mile radius of earthworks and trenches that surrounded the town. The fort was 400 feet square, rectangular with a moat, composed of slanted timbers on the outer walls, located one mile south of town on a hill along US 63. Some remains on private property at the Wyman School. Over 20,000 troops were garrisoned in the town. Marker located at 262 North Main Street at the Old Phelps County Courthouse (1860). See also History of Rolla in the Civil War Fort Dette (1863 - 1865), a Union cross-shaped fort on the north-side of town. Also spelled Detty . Site located on the campus of the University of Missouri-Rolla. No remains. Camp Carey Gratz (1861 - 1865), a Union camp located near town. It became for a time the Headquarters, Army of the West.

description_raw: A temporary stockade erected by the settlers, it was abandoned after they were killed by Indians.
entry_raw: Clarksville Stockade (1812), Clarksville - A temporary stockade erected by the settlers, it was abandoned after they were killed by Indians.

description_raw: A settlers' log fort built by Colonel John Coontz and his brother Nicholas, located on Boone's Lick Road one and one-half miles east of town. The original house was built in 1800. Became a tavern after the war. Site is marked with a monument as Kountz Fort , which family descendants claim is a misspelling.
entry_raw: Coontz's Fort (1812 - 1815), Cottleville - A settlers' log fort built by Colonel John Coontz and his brother Nicholas, located on Boone's Lick Road one and one-half miles east of town. The original house was built in 1800. Became a tavern after the war. Site is marked with a monument as Kountz Fort , which family descendants claim is a misspelling.

description_raw: A settlers' fort built by the son of the famous pioneer, with two or three blockhouses. Located in Darst's Bottom on Femme Osage Creek.
entry_raw: Daniel Morgan Boone's Fort (1812 - 1815), Matson - A settlers' fort built by the son of the famous pioneer, with two or three blockhouses. Located in Darst's Bottom on Femme Osage Creek.

description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort with several cabins forming the walls, located about one mile west of town.
entry_raw: David Kinkead's Fort (1812 - 1815), near Franklin - A settlers' stockaded fort with several cabins forming the walls, located about one mile west of town.

description_raw: A settlers' fort.
entry_raw: Femme Osage Fort (1812 - 1815), Mechanicsville - A settlers' fort.

description_raw: A Union fort built on Fort Hill. Captured by the Confederates in April 1861, and again in September 1864, when it was finally destroyed.
entry_raw: Fort Benton (1861 - 1864), Patterson - A Union fort built on Fort Hill. Captured by the Confederates in April 1861, and again in September 1864, when it was finally destroyed.

description_raw: A Union fort located on Bunker Hill (named after the war), near the present St. Charles Reservoir. A school was used as barracks, site now Mount Pleasant School. Two nearby mills were used as a hospital and a prison.
entry_raw: Fort Bunker (1861 - unknown), St. Charles - A Union fort located on Bunker Hill (named after the war), near the present St. Charles Reservoir. A school was used as barracks, site now Mount Pleasant School. Two nearby mills were used as a hospital and a prison.

description_raw: A Spanish trading fort built in the Osage Nation by St. Louis fur trade brothers Auguste and Pierre Chouteau Sr.. Located on a limestone bluff on the south side of the Osage River, below the Great Osage Village, and upstream from Panther Creek. The fort was sold to fur trader Manuel Lisa in 1802. Pierre Chouteau Sr. traded with the Osage here (or very nearby) as early as 1784.
entry_raw: Fort Carondelet (1791 - 1804), near Schell City - A Spanish trading fort built in the Osage Nation by St. Louis fur trade brothers Auguste and Pierre Chouteau Sr.. Located on a limestone bluff on the south side of the Osage River, below the Great Osage Village, and upstream from Panther Creek. The fort was sold to fur trader Manuel Lisa in 1802. Pierre Chouteau Sr. traded with the Osage here (or very nearby) as early as 1784.

description_raw: A local militia fort located on the upper part of Loutre Island. Also known as Camp Clemson .
entry_raw: Fort Clemson (1812 - 1815), near McKittrick - A local militia fort located on the upper part of Loutre Island. Also known as Camp Clemson .

alt_names: Joseph Thibault's (Tibeau's, Tebo's) Fort|Jean Baptiste Roi's (Roy's) Fort
description_raw: A reference to two settlers' blockhouse forts located opposite the mouth of the Osage River, Joseph Thibault's (Tibeau's, Tebo's) Fort and Jean Baptiste Roi's (Roy's) Fort , about 400 yards apart with a log powder magazine between the two. They were attacked by Sauk and Fox Indians in April 1815 who attempted to burn the blockhouses. The settlers put out each attempt first with their drinking water, then their milk supply, and then with the contents of their bed chamberpots. The Indians then fled the scene.
entry_raw: Fort Cte sans Dessein (1812 - 1815), near Tebbetts - A reference to two settlers' blockhouse forts located opposite the mouth of the Osage River, Joseph Thibault's (Tibeau's, Tebo's) Fort and Jean Baptiste Roi's (Roy's) Fort , about 400 yards apart with a log powder magazine between the two. They were attacked by Sauk and Fox Indians in April 1815 who attempted to burn the blockhouses. The settlers put out each attempt first with their drinking water, then their milk supply, and then with the contents of their bed chamberpots. The Indians then fled the scene.

alt_names: Fort Don Carlos el Seor Prncipe de Asturias|Fort San Carlos el Rey, Don Carlos Tercero|Fort San Carlos del Misuri
description_raw: A Spanish fort built on the south side of the mouth of the Missouri River. It was officially known as Fort Don Carlos el Seor Prncipe de Asturias , and it was an 80-foot square palisade with four bastions. Located on the north side of the river was Spanish Fort San Carlos el Rey, Don Carlos Tercero , also known as Fort San Carlos del Misuri . It was a log blockhouse 18-feet square and 7-feet high, with a five-man garrison. It was abandoned and destroyed by the Spanish in May 1780 as the British were preparing to attack St. Louis .
entry_raw: Fort Don Carlos (1767 - 1769, 1779 - 1780), Spanish Lake - A Spanish fort built on the south side of the mouth of the Missouri River. It was officially known as Fort Don Carlos el Seor Prncipe de Asturias , and it was an 80-foot square palisade with four bastions. Located on the north side of the river was Spanish Fort San Carlos el Rey, Don Carlos Tercero , also known as Fort San Carlos del Misuri . It was a log blockhouse 18-feet square and 7-feet high, with a five-man garrison. It was abandoned and destroyed by the Spanish in May 1780 as the British were preparing to attack St. Louis .

description_raw: A Union fort probably located at the Lambert Ford on Dry Wood Creek, south of town on Stockade Road (County Road HH). Garrisoned by Wisconsin cavalry.
entry_raw: Fort Hamer (1865), near Deerfield - A Union fort probably located at the Lambert Ford on Dry Wood Creek, south of town on Stockade Road (County Road HH). Garrisoned by Wisconsin cavalry.

description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort with two blockhouses, located one mile north of town near Sulphur Creek. It was originally named Rev. David McLain's (or McClain ) Fort . Renamed after Captain Stephen Hempstead of the local militia.
entry_raw: Fort Hempstead (1812 - 1815), New Franklin - A settlers' stockaded fort with two blockhouses, located one mile north of town near Sulphur Creek. It was originally named Rev. David McLain's (or McClain ) Fort . Renamed after Captain Stephen Hempstead of the local militia.

description_raw: A Union earthen and timber fort built on Fort Hill, protecting the southern approach to the Arcadia Valley. Renamed Fort Curtis (1) in 1863. Six guns were reported in 1863. Abandoned and dismantled just prior to the battle at Fort Davidson (September 1864). Site at 103 Church Street, now Fort Hill Apostolic Church.
entry_raw: Fort Hovey (1861 - 1864), Arcadia - A Union earthen and timber fort built on Fort Hill, protecting the southern approach to the Arcadia Valley. Renamed Fort Curtis (1) in 1863. Six guns were reported in 1863. Abandoned and dismantled just prior to the battle at Fort Davidson (September 1864). Site at 103 Church Street, now Fort Hill Apostolic Church.

description_raw: A local militia stockaded fort with three blockhouses, built under orders from Captain Nathan Boone. Garrisoned by 60 - 70 men, and accommodating 30 families. The "Battle of the Sinkhole" occurred here in May 1815.
entry_raw: Fort Howard (1812 - 1815), Old Monroe - A local militia stockaded fort with three blockhouses, built under orders from Captain Nathan Boone. Garrisoned by 60 - 70 men, and accommodating 30 families. The "Battle of the Sinkhole" occurred here in May 1815.

description_raw: A local militia fort built by the Missouri Rangers, located two miles east of town, eight miles above the mouth of the Cuivre River, opposite Cap au Gris on the Illinois-side of the Mississippi River. Also known as Cap au Grs Fort (aka Capo Gray). Burned in 1813 shortly after being built, but reoccupied until the end of the war.

description_raw: A Federal fort protecting the settlement here from Indian raids, located about 15 miles north of the mouth of the Salt River. Built by a detachment of the U.S. First Infantry Regiment (about 20 men) from Fort Belle Fontaine, under command of Lt. John Campbell, with assistance from a Missouri Ranger company commanded by Capt. Nathan Boone, and garrisoned until late April 1813. ( NOTE: The fort may or may not have been named for Lt. John Mason of Col. Kibby's Rangers from St. Charles ; or was possibly named for Mary Mason Howard, the wife of Missouri Territorial Governor Benjamin Howard, and sister to a John T. Mason. Mary Mason died in Kentucky in March 1813.)

description_raw: A French fort. This was the first permanent settlement in the state. Local traders also built a fort here in 1785, called Fort St. Joachim . It was rebuilt at least twice before 1804.

description_raw: A Union stone-walled infantry redoubt located on the bluff overlooking the north end of the Iron Mountain Railroad bridge over the Big River just south of town. The bridge was destroyed by Confederates in October 1861, the only recorded Civil War action in Jefferson County.

description_raw: A settlers' fort located on Howell's Prairie near Dardenne Creek, now within the August A. Busch Wildlife Area.

description_raw: A fur trade post located on an island along the north bank of the Missouri River, under the "Randolph Bluffs", about three miles below the mouth of the Kansas River. Also known as Kansas Post . Destroyed by a flood/mud slide in the spring of 1826, the occupants escaped unharmed and fled upriver to Chouteau's "Four Houses" post on the Kansas River in present-day De Soto , KS (see also) . Franois was the son of Pierre Sr..

Destroyed by a flood/mud slide in the spring of 1826, the occupants escaped unharmed and fled upriver to Chouteau's "Four Houses" post on the Kansas River in present-day De Soto , KS (see also) . description_raw: A settlers' stockaded fort on a bluff on the eastern side of town, built after Stephen's fort was attacked and then abandoned in December 1814. Hannah's husband William Cole (who was killed by Indians in 1810) was Stephen's brother. Became the first Howard County courthouse in 1816. Marker on Monroe Street. The bluff was later leveled to build the railroad through town. The 1910 "Hannah Cole Cottage" bed and breakfast inn, located at 1209 East Morgan, is said to be located at or near the fort site.

description_raw: A short-lived sub-post of the Fort Osage Indian Factory, located on the Marais des Cygnes River about five miles upstream from the Osage River. Also known as (Little) Osage River Post . The Federal government closed down the Indian Factory system in 1822. Auguste Pierre Chouteau soon thereafter opened a trading post here in 1823 that was operated by his brothers Cyprian Chouteau and Franois Gesseau Chouteau.

alt_names: Fort Celeste|Post at New Madrid|Fort Bankhead|Fort Thompson|Island Number 10
description_raw: A settlers' trading post was first located here. The Spanish built Fort Celeste (1789 - 1804, rebuilt 1796), an eight-gun, moated, square palisade with four blockhouses. The original work was built too close to the river, and eroded during a flood. The second fort was burned in 1801, but rebuilt. The Americans briefly occupied the Spanish fort in 1804, but then built Post at New Madrid (1804 - 1808). Confederate earthworks Fort Bankhead (seven guns) and Fort Thompson (14 guns) protected the land approach to the city, and 19 guns were located on Island Number 10 . The city was captured by the Union, with the Confederates retreating across the river to Watson's Point, setting up several new shore batteries and a floating battery (see TENNESSEE page) . When Island Number 10 was captured by the Union, the Confederates abandoned the other batteries. Island Number 10 no longer exists today as it did then due to erosion and shifting currents. The sites of the two Confederate forts and the Union seige lines were marked on a new driving tour in 2012. Exhibits are located in the New Madrid Historical Museum (admission fee) at 1 South Main Street. See also Civil War in New Madrid and the Battle of Island Number 10 from City of New Madrid
entry_raw: New Madrid Forts (1783 - unknown, 1789 - 1804, 1804 - 1808, 1862), New Madrid - A settlers' trading post was first located here. The Spanish built Fort Celeste (1789 - 1804, rebuilt 1796), an eight-gun, moated, square palisade with four blockhouses. The original work was built too close to the river, and eroded during a flood. The second fort was burned in 1801, but rebuilt. The Americans briefly occupied the Spanish fort in 1804, but then built Post at New Madrid (1804 - 1808). Confederate earthworks Fort Bankhead (seven guns) and Fort Thompson (14 guns) protected the land approach to the city, and 19 guns were located on Island Number 10 . The city was captured by the Union, with the Confederates retreating across the river to Watson's Point, setting up several new shore batteries and a floating battery (see TENNESSEE page) . When Island Number 10 was captured by the Union, the Confederates abandoned the other batteries. Island Number 10 no longer exists today as it did then due to erosion and shifting currents. The sites of the two Confederate forts and the Union seige lines were marked on a new driving tour in 2012. Exhibits are located in the New Madrid Historical Museum (admission fee) at 1 South Main Street. See also Civil War in New Madrid and the Battle of Island Number 10 from City of New Madrid

description_raw: A Berthold and Chouteau company trading post, built by Joseph Robideaux, located near the mouth of the Nishnabotna River, across from Peru , Nebraska. It was sold to the American Fur Company probably by 1828.
entry_raw: Nishnabotna Post (1819 - 1833), near Watson - A Berthold and Chouteau company trading post, built by Joseph Robideaux, located near the mouth of the Nishnabotna River, across from Peru , Nebraska. It was sold to the American Fur Company probably by 1828.

description_raw: A circular stone tower wind-powered gristmill constructed in 1797 by Spanish trader Antoine Roy (Roi), built of notched stone 30-feet high and 30-feet in diameter. It was located at present-day Third and Adams Streets. It was never used as a fort, but the fog of history mystified its origins. It was torn down after the Civil War.
entry_raw: Old Round Stone Fort (1797), St. Charles - A circular stone tower wind-powered gristmill constructed in 1797 by Spanish trader Antoine Roy (Roi), built of notched stone 30-feet high and 30-feet in diameter. It was located at present-day Third and Adams Streets. It was never used as a fort, but the fog of history mystified its origins. It was torn down after the Civil War.

description_raw: One of three circular stone towers built by the Spanish, located near the river at the foot of Biddle Street. It was the last remaining Spanish defensive structure, and a notable local landmark, until torn down in 1860. A second tower was located on the west side of Third Street, between St. Charles Street and Washington Ave.. The Union Enginehouse was built on the site in 1836. The third tower was located at Sycamore and Second Streets. A stone blockhouse was built on the north side of Chouteau Ave., between Third and Fourth Streets.
entry_raw: Old Spanish Fort (1797 - 1805), St. Louis - One of three circular stone towers built by the Spanish, located near the river at the foot of Biddle Street. It was the last remaining Spanish defensive structure, and a notable local landmark, until torn down in 1860. A second tower was located on the west side of Third Street, between St. Charles Street and Washington Ave.. The Union Enginehouse was built on the site in 1836. The third tower was located at Sycamore and Second Streets. A stone blockhouse was built on the north side of Chouteau Ave., between Third and Fourth Streets.

description_raw: A trade post near the Big Osage villages, established by Pierre Millicour Papin, cousin to Auguste Pierre Chouteau.
entry_raw: Papinsville (1816 - 1822), Papinsville - A trade post near the Big Osage villages, established by Pierre Millicour Papin, cousin to Auguste Pierre Chouteau.

description_raw: The Missouri Valley Hotel (1850), a substantial stone structure, was fortified in July 1864 by the so-called "Paw-Paw Militia", the 82nd Enrolled Missouri Militia home guards of Platte County (a nominally Union outfit populated with mostly ex-Confederates and Southern-leaning sympathizers), upon the advance of Confederate partisan rangers under John Thornton and Charles Taylor (which included Frank and Jesse James). The town, and the hotel, were surrendered without a fight, the garrison captured as prisoners (several of which then joined the partisans). The hotel later became the first structure of Park College in 1876, but was dismantled in the early 20th-century during railroad expansion along the river bluff.
entry_raw: Paw-Paw Fort (1864), Parkville - The Missouri Valley Hotel (1850), a substantial stone structure, was fortified in July 1864 by the so-called "Paw-Paw Militia", the 82nd Enrolled Missouri Militia home guards of Platte County (a nominally Union outfit populated with mostly ex-Confederates and Southern-leaning sympathizers), upon the advance of Confederate partisan rangers under John Thornton and Charles Taylor (which included Frank and Jesse James). The town, and the hotel, were surrendered without a fight, the garrison captured as prisoners (several of which then joined the partisans). The hotel later became the first structure of Park College in 1876, but was dismantled in the early 20th-century during railroad expansion along the river bluff.

Confederate artillery that shelled the town was placed at the present-day Crown Hill Cemetery on Veterans Memorial Drive, which was just northeast of the Union earthwork.

description_raw: A Union fort guarding the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad bridge over the South River, south of town. Garrisoned by a company of the 19th Illinois Infantry, commanded by Col. John B. Turchin. This post was the only garrisoned post in this part of the state for the duration of the war. This section of the old rail line, between Hannibal and Palmyra , no longer exists. A reconstruction of the fort was once located at the Civil War Fort and Museum at 4805 McMasters Ave. in nearby Hannibal , but has since been closed and torn down.
entry_raw: South River Fort (1861 - 1865), near Palmyra - A Union fort guarding the Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroad bridge over the South River, south of town. Garrisoned by a company of the 19th Illinois Infantry, commanded by Col. John B. Turchin. This post was the only garrisoned post in this part of the state for the duration of the war. This section of the old rail line, between Hannibal and Palmyra , no longer exists. A reconstruction of the fort was once located at the Civil War Fort and Museum at 4805 McMasters Ave. in nearby Hannibal , but has since been closed and torn down.

description_raw: A Spanish fort was proposed several times after the American Revolution to be built at the mouth of the Des Moines River to prevent British (Canadian) traders from the western fur trade. It was never constructed. (See also Montbrun's Fort in IOWA)

entry_raw: St. Charles Post (1804 - unknown), St. Charles - A Federal stockaded post located at the foot of Clay Street. Later used as a trading post. Site was destroyed in 1960 for a parking lot.

description_raw: A Union garrison post during the Civil War. The 1858 Patee House Museum (admission fee) at 1202 Penn Street was used as the Union Provost Marshal's office. Located on Prospect Hill at the end of West Michel Street (at Bellevue Street), overlooking the Missouri River just north of downtown, was Fort Smith , an earthen redoubt for 12 guns and 2500 troops. No remains, site excavated in 2007 (part of the Huston Wyeth Park green space).

Located on Prospect Hill at the end of West Michel Street (at Bellevue Street), overlooking the Missouri River just north of downtown, was Fort Smith , an earthen redoubt for 12 guns and 2500 troops. description_raw: Once located in the present-day downtown area along the Mississippi River (at the Second Terrace) was a Mississippian Culture palisaded temple mound complex, encompassing 23 mounds within a bastioned palisade. The site was surveyed in 1819. The Sugarloaf Mound is the only precontact period structure still extant today, located at 4420 Ohio Avenue (private property) near the Mt. Pleasant neighborhood, south of downtown off of South 1st Street. The Osage Indian Nation purchased the property in 2009 with the intent to preserve the mound to its original condition.
entry_raw: St. Louis Mounds (900 - 1450), St. Louis - Once located in the present-day downtown area along the Mississippi River (at the Second Terrace) was a Mississippian Culture palisaded temple mound complex, encompassing 23 mounds within a bastioned palisade. The site was surveyed in 1819. The Sugarloaf Mound is the only precontact period structure still extant today, located at 4420 Ohio Avenue (private property) near the Mt. Pleasant neighborhood, south of downtown off of South 1st Street. The Osage Indian Nation purchased the property in 2009 with the intent to preserve the mound to its original condition.

description_raw: A French settlers' palisaded complex of log cabins, located on the hill at present-day Fourth and Walnut Streets. This was the first white settlement of the city. The French had earlier built a crude fort (1700 - 1703) here at an Illini Indian village at the mouth of the "River Des Peres".

description_raw: An American Army hospital during the Mexican-American War (July - November 1848), located on the southern point of the island. Consisted of four large wooden barracks (for 300 men) arranged in a square, with several store houses and a wharf. The complex was destroyed by a series of three hurricanes in 1859-60, but still remained a Federal military reservation until 1907. Greenwood Island is heavily industrialized today, and not accessible to the general public. State marker located in the 3200 block of Beach Blvd..

description_raw: Confederate trenches and earthworks surrounded the town on the north, west, and south, and are still located in Battlefield Park at Langley Street and Terry Road, and at the Manship House on East Fortification Street. Fortification Street marks the east-west defensive line. Union trenches were located west of the CSA line. A Union battery is still extant near the VA Hospital. The city was attacked after the fall of Vicksburg . See also Civil War Album.com Camp Patrick Henry (1) (1861 - 1863) was a CSA recruiting camp located near today's Millsaps College.

description_raw: A Union blockhouse converted from an old sawmill, and earthworks on an old Indian mound nearby, to protect the railroad bridge across the Wolf River. Unsuccessfully attacked several times by the Confederates. The settlement was then known as Davis' Mills .

description_raw: A militia fort located at the old Plymouth townsite at Plymouth Bluff, on the west bank of the Tombigbee River at Tibbee Creek just northwest of Columbus . A log stockade was built around the house (1810) of John Pitchlynn, the U.S. appointed interpreter to the Choctaw Nation, and the Choctaw Indian Agency sub-agent. A two-story log blockhouse was also built to house the garrison of troops posted here, which included some U.S. regulars and 20 Choctaw warriors. The fort was so-named after or by Capt. George Smith of the Tennessee Militia, in the fall of 1813. The fort was used as a supply depot and assembly point during the First Creek War. Davy Crockett was said to have passed through here in October 1814. The fort was almost attacked twice by the Creeks, according to Peter Pitchlynn's later memoirs, who was about seven or eight years old at the time of the war. The town was abandoned by the 1850's. The last remnants of the log fort were documented to have been removed by the then landowner, Orlando Canfield, in 1860, for the building of several plantation houses. Site now inundated by Columbus Lake (impounded by the completion of the Columbus/John C. Stennis Lock and Dam in 1981). Artifacts and history of the area is interpreted at the Plymouth Bluff Environmental Center at 2200 Old West Point Road, operated by the Mississippi University for Women.

A log stockade was built around the house (1810) of John Pitchlynn, the U.S. appointed interpreter to the Choctaw Nation, and the Choctaw Indian Agency sub-agent. A two-story log blockhouse was also built to house the garrison of troops posted here, which included some U.S. regulars and 20 Choctaw warriors. The fort was so-named after or by Capt. Davy Crockett was said to have passed through here in October 1814. The fort was almost attacked twice by the Creeks, according to Peter Pitchlynn's later memoirs, who was about seven or eight years old at the time of the war. The town was abandoned by the 1850's. The last remnants of the log fort were documented to have been removed by the then landowner, Orlando Canfield, in 1860, for the building of several plantation houses. Site now inundated by Columbus Lake (impounded by the completion of the Columbus/John C. Stennis Lock and Dam in 1981). Artifacts and history of the area is interpreted at the Plymouth Bluff Environmental Center at 2200 Old West Point Road, operated by the Mississippi University for Women.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. 100-foot square stockaded trading post located on the north bank of the Yellowstone River (near the mouth of Armells Creek ?), about 12-15 miles upstream from Fort Van Buren, just northwest of town about halfway between Big and Little Porcupine Creeks. Built by Charles Larpenteur to replace Fort Van Buren. The Blackfeet Indians referred to this post as Fort Crow as an insult to Larpenteur. It was burned down when abandoned. No trace remains.
entry_raw: Fort Alexander (Culbertson) (1) (1842 - 1850), near Forsyth - An American Fur Co. 100-foot square stockaded trading post located on the north bank of the Yellowstone River (near the mouth of Armells Creek ?), about 12-15 miles upstream from Fort Van Buren, just northwest of town about halfway between Big and Little Porcupine Creeks. Built by Charles Larpenteur to replace Fort Van Buren. The Blackfeet Indians referred to this post as Fort Crow as an insult to Larpenteur. It was burned down when abandoned. No trace remains.

description_raw: A temporary 100-foot square stockaded American Fur Co. trading post and depot on the Missouri River, somewhere near the mouth of the Poplar River, where the steamboat Assiniboine , in the summer of 1834, went aground on a sandbar, during the first known attempt to ascend the river past Fort Union. Unable to free the vessel before winter, the traders built a suitable post for the duration. The boat was not freed until the following March. The American Fur Co. used the site again during the next winter season. Exact location undetermined.
entry_raw: Fort Assiniboine (1) (1834 - 1835, 1835 - 1836), near Poplar - A temporary 100-foot square stockaded American Fur Co. trading post and depot on the Missouri River, somewhere near the mouth of the Poplar River, where the steamboat Assiniboine , in the summer of 1834, went aground on a sandbar, during the first known attempt to ascend the river past Fort Union. Unable to free the vessel before winter, the traders built a suitable post for the duration. The boat was not freed until the following March. The American Fur Co. used the site again during the next winter season. Exact location undetermined.

description_raw: A St. Louis Missouri Fur Co. trading post located on the Yellowstone River somewhere near Fort Manuel, probably a mile or so downstream. Built by Michael Immell and Robert Jones in the fall of 1822, after Andrew Henry and William Ashley had built Fort Henry that summer at the mouth of the Yellowstone River in present-day Buford , ND. Both Immell and Jones were killed by Blackfeet Indians in the spring of 1823.
entry_raw: Fort Benton (1) (1822 - 1823), near Bighorn - A St. Louis Missouri Fur Co. trading post located on the Yellowstone River somewhere near Fort Manuel, probably a mile or so downstream. Built by Michael Immell and Robert Jones in the fall of 1822, after Andrew Henry and William Ashley had built Fort Henry that summer at the mouth of the Yellowstone River in present-day Buford , ND. Both Immell and Jones were killed by Blackfeet Indians in the spring of 1823.

description_raw: An independent trader's 100-foot square stockaded trading post on the north bank of the Yellowstone River, seven miles below the Big Horn River. It was abandoned and then burned by Indians in March 1876. Fellows D. Pease was previously the government agent to the Crow Indians before he took up trading. Army troops later encamped here briefly in the summer of 1876.

description_raw: An American Fur Co. trading post on the north side of the Yellowstone River opposite the mouth of Rosebud Creek (just east of town), operated by Samuel Tulloch. Replaced Fort Cass. It was burned down when abandoned in the summer of 1842, after Charles Larpenteur took over, and replaced by Fort Alexander (1). This was the American Fur Company's second post built on the Yellowstone River.

description_raw: A state National Guard summer tent camp located west of town, in the former Carolina City area. Following World War I it became a Navy base (1918 - 1920). Then it became the first U.S. Coast Guard air station (1920 - 1921). The Navy returned in 1941 establishing an Area Section Base.

description_raw: A major Loyalist/Tory stronghold before the Battle of King's Mountain (October 1780), established by Major Patrick "Bull Dog" Ferguson. The old townsite was located on the west side of Cathy's Creek north of town. State marker located on US 221.

description_raw: A major Patriot encampment established initially by Major General Baron DeKalb. Patriot Major General Horatio Gates retreated here after the Battle of Camden (August 1780). British Major General Cornwallis occupied the town in February 1781. Tory raiders under Col. David Fanning captured the town and Governor Thomas Burke in September 1781, precipitating the Battle of Lindley's Mill.

David Fanning captured the town and Governor Thomas Burke in September 1781, precipitating the Battle of Lindley's Mill.

See also Guilford Courthouse National Military Park

alt_names: Camp Argyle|Camp Burgwyn (1)|Camp Canal|Camp Vance (3)|Camp Wilkes
description_raw: Confederate troops established several camps here and nearby before the town was taken by the Union in April 1862 during the Fort Macon campaign. Marker at Morehead City Park at 10th and Arendell Streets. CSA camps located in the general area were: Camp Argyle , unknown exact location, used from October to December 1861; Camp Burgwyn (1) located at Atlantic Beach ; Camp Canal in Morehead City ; Camp Vance (3) one mile west of the town, used as winter quarters from November 1861 to January 1862; Camp Wilkes (1861) two miles from Fort Macon.
entry_raw: Carolina City Encampments (1861 - 1862), Morehead City - Confederate troops established several camps here and nearby before the town was taken by the Union in April 1862 during the Fort Macon campaign. Marker at Morehead City Park at 10th and Arendell Streets. CSA camps located in the general area were: Camp Argyle , unknown exact location, used from October to December 1861; Camp Burgwyn (1) located at Atlantic Beach ; Camp Canal in Morehead City ; Camp Vance (3) one mile west of the town, used as winter quarters from November 1861 to January 1862; Camp Wilkes (1861) two miles from Fort Macon.

description_raw: British settlers from Barbados led by John Vassall attempted an early colony here. Vassall sailed to Cape Fear in May 1664 and selected a site on a high bluff on the west side of the Cape Fear River north of Town Creek. He erected a fortified compound with several buildings. Within two years about 800 people were living in the colony. Many chose to settle along the branches of the river, seeking out the higher ground, some as far as sixty miles from the main settlement. Politics, however, soon favored a new site at Port Royal , SC. Abandoned by 1667. A second "Charles Towne", backed by many of the same Barbadians, arose on the Ashley River in 1670. State marker located on NC 133 at the Town Creek bridge north of Pinelevel .
entry_raw: Charles Towne (1664 - 1667), Old Town - British settlers from Barbados led by John Vassall attempted an early colony here. Vassall sailed to Cape Fear in May 1664 and selected a site on a high bluff on the west side of the Cape Fear River north of Town Creek. He erected a fortified compound with several buildings. Within two years about 800 people were living in the colony. Many chose to settle along the branches of the river, seeking out the higher ground, some as far as sixty miles from the main settlement. Politics, however, soon favored a new site at Port Royal , SC. Abandoned by 1667. A second "Charles Towne", backed by many of the same Barbadians, arose on the Ashley River in 1670. State marker located on NC 133 at the Town Creek bridge north of Pinelevel .

description_raw: The British army under Major General Cornwallis encamped here in October 1780 and again in February 1781. The Patriot army under Major General Gates was here in November 1780, and where Major General Nathanael Greene took over command of the Southern Continental Army. Of interest here is the Hezekiah Alexander homesite (1774), operated by the Charlotte Museum of History.

Of interest here is the Hezekiah Alexander homesite (1774), operated by the Charlotte Museum of History.

alt_names: Camp Blackjack|Camp Campbell|Camp Daniel|Camp Hamilton|Camp Hilton|Camp Hoke|Camp Johnston|Camp Martin|Camp Nethercutt|Camp Pool|Camp Ransom (2)|Sandy Ridge Camp|Gum Swamp Fort|Camp Southwest
description_raw: CSA camps included: Camp Blackjack (1862 - 1865), located five miles east of town near Graingers . Camp Campbell (1861) Camp Daniel Camp Hamilton Camp Hilton Camp Hoke Camp Johnston , located near Hardison Crossroads on Falling Creek. Camp Martin Camp Nethercutt Camp Pool (1862), located on Tower Hill Road near Georgetown . Earthworks consisting of a 50-yard semi-circular work with a 50-yard infantry trench, and several gun emplacements still exist along the north bank of the Neuse River. Seven guns were abandoned here when the Union attacked the town in December 1862. Camp Ransom (2) (1863), located at Wyse Fork . Union trenchworks (March 1865) still exist here. Sandy Ridge Camp (1863), located near Dover on Old Dover Road. Gum Swamp Fort (1863), located one mile west of Dover . A battle was fought here in January 1863. Camp Southwest (1862 - 1865), CSA earthworks are well-preserved along the north bank of Southwest Creek near Woodington , with two batteries on each end of the line. Site of battle March 1865. The 56-acre site, purchased in 2004 by the Historical Preservation Group, is not yet open for public access. CSA earthworks also were once located along Southwest Creek in Caswell , and in South Kinston guarding the old railroad bridge across the Neuse river.

name_primary: Civil War Defenses of New Bern
alt_names: Fort Astor|Fort Brown|Fort Holmes (1)|Camp Gatlin|Fort Totten|Fort Rowan|Fort Dutton|Fort Union|Fort Stevenson|Fort Amory|Camp Amory|Camp Pendleton|Fort Spinola|Camp Massachusetts|Fort Gaston|Camp Gaston|Camp Pierce|Old Fort|Fort Anderson (2)|Fort Chase|Fort Pearson|Camp Reno (2)|Camp Andrews
description_raw: Early Confederate defenses included: Fort Astor , located south of town on the north-bank of the Trent River. Fort Brown (eight guns), undetermined location. Fort Holmes (1) , undetermined location. Camp Gatlin , located behind Fort Lane. Trenches were built from the Neuse River to the Trent River west of town after the town was captured by Union forces in March 1862, with a fort in the center and a fort at each end. Fort Totten , a 28-gun seven-acre five-bastioned fort that was the southern anchor of the western line. No remains, site now on private property. Marker at Fort Totten Drive and Trent Blvd.. Fort Rowan , the middle fort in the line, a five-gun four-pointed star fort guarding the railroad into town. Fort Dutton (aka Fort Union ), at the north-end of the line at the Neuse River. Fort Stevenson , a five-gun work located just west (upriver) from Fort Dutton. An unnamed fort was located in town at the railroad bridge across the Trent River. South of town across the Trent River in James City was an additional line of Union works, with a blockhouse in the center on the railroad coming from the south. Fort Amory , at the west-end on the Trent River. Parts of its ramparts and ditch can still be seen. Camp Amory was adjacent. Camp Pendleton was also nearby. Fort Spinola , at the east-end on the Neuse River, near Fort Point and the former CSA Fort Lane. Camp Massachusetts was adjacent. Fort Gaston , a palisaded two-gun fort guarding an old bridge across the Trent River, south of Fort Amory and north of the mouth of Brice Creek. Camp Gaston (previously a CSA camp site) was located outside the palisade. Earthworks still remain on private property. Camp Pierce , undetermined location, previously a CSA camp site. Located at the mouth of Brice Creek was a Union post at Old Fort (probably originally CSA in 1861). A blockhouse was also further south along Brice Creek, guarding a Union cavalry camp. Located across the Neuse River from New Bern were: Fort Anderson (2) , near the mouth of Mills Branch, directly north of Fort Dutton. Attacked by Confederates in 1863. Fort Chase in Bridgeton , directly across from New Bern . Union Fort Pearson (1864), undetermined location. Union Camp Reno (2) (1862), undetermined location. Union Camp Andrews (1862) (previously a CSA camp site), undetermined location. Several Confederate batteries (1862) were located along the Neuse River from New Bern to Kinston to prevent further Union advances. Civil War exhibits are at the 1766 New Bern Academy Museum located at New and Hancock Streets, once used as a hospital during the war. Administered by the Tryon Palace Historic Site .
